  • Symptoms include low plasma bicarbonate, glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and hypokalemia
  • The urine pH may be acidic when plasma bicarbonate is low.

Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 1)
  • Results from an inability to acidify the urine in the distal tubule.
  • Characterized by persistently high urine pH (>5.5), hypokalemia, and a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Often associated with nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis. (Option A)

Hyperkalemic Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 4)
  • Characterized by hyperkalemia and a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Common in conditions such as diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. (Option C)

 

D) While CKD can lead to metabolic acidosis, it typically presents with features such as elevated serum creatinine and urea levels and a mixed acid-base disturbance that may include both metabolic acidosis and changes in electrolyte balance. The patient's specific findings are more indicative of proximal RTA rather than CKD alone.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is scheduled for elective surgery requiring general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist decides to use thiopental sodium as an induction agent. Which of the following statements is true about thiopental sodium?

choices.text: It has a long duration of action due to extensive renal metabolism.
Its rapid onset is primarily due to its high potency and redistribution.
It appears as a white milky liquid.
Its elimination half-life is approximately 1 hour.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Its rapid onset is primarily due to its high potency and redistribution.

Explanation: Thiopental sodium has a rapid onset due to its high lipid solubility and high nonionized fraction, allowing for quick redistribution from the bloodstream to the brain.

Thiopentone Sodium:

  • Use: Intravenous induction agent.
  • Prepared concentration: 2.5% solution
  • Form: Yellowish-white crystalline powder or pale greenish hygroscopic powder (Option C)
  • Odor: Garlic-like odor.
  • Formulation: Thiopental sodium for injection is a sterile mixture of thiopental sodium and anhydrous sodium carbonate (buffer).
  • Should not be reconstituted with lactated Ringer’s solution or mixed with acidic solutions, as this reduces alkalinity and may cause precipitation of the drug as free acid.
  • pH: 11
  • Melting Point: The free acid (thiopental) melts at 158–160°C.
  • Solubility:
    • Water: Soluble in 1.5 parts of water at 20°C.
  • Alcohol: Partially soluble.
  • Insoluble: Practically insoluble in ether, benzene, and petroleum ether.
  • Pharmacokinetics:
    • Higher potency.
    • Rapid onset and short duration of action. 
    • Dose: 3-6 mg/kg
    • Duration of onset: 15-20 seconds
    • Duration of action: 6-10 minutes
    • Elimination T1/2: 12 hours (Option D)
    • Exhibits first-order kinetics.
    • Unique property: Duration of induction dose is determined by redistribution.
    • Metabolism and excretion site: Liver (Option A)

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus is currently managed on metformin and gliclazide. However, his diabetes is not well-controlled, and he requires insulin therapy. He has a busy work schedule and prefers a regimen that minimises the number of daily injections. Which of the following insulin regimens would be most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Insulin glargine once daily in the evening and Lispro three times before major meals
A premixed combination of regular and NPH insulin twice daily
Insulin Aspart injected before each meal
CSII with regular insulin using an insulin pump

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A premixed combination of regular and NPH insulin twice daily

Explanation;

A premixed combination of regular and NPH insulin offers the convenience of twice-daily injections while addressing basal and prandial insulin needs.

  • Mixtard insulin is a pre-mixed combination of regular insulin and isophane insulin.
  • It is used in a split-mixed regimen, where the total daily dose is split and injected twice daily, before breakfast and dinner.
  • Two formulations are available: A 30:70 mixture of regular and isophane insulin and a 50:50 mixture of regular and isophane insulin.
  • Regular insulin has a rapid onset and short duration of action, while isophane insulin has a longer duration of action.

 

PROPERTY

INTERMEDIATE-ACTING INSULIN

Specific preparation

Insulin zinc suspension (Lente insulin), Neutral protamine Hagedorn (NPH) insulin, or isophane insulin

Appearance

Cloudy solution

Onset of action

1-2 hours

Peak effect

8-10 hours

Effective duration

12-20 hours (Lente), 12-20 hours (NPH)

Compatibility

Can be mixed with regular insulin

Disadvantages

The time course of absorption and intensity of action are relatively inconsistent

Major adverse effect

Hypoglycemia

Additional Information

Intermediate-acting insulin is formulated to prolong insulin absorption.

It is often combined with regular insulin in a split-mixed regimen, subcutaneously twice daily, before breakfast and dinner.

Lente - Insulin zinc suspension.

NPH insulin is formulated by adding protamine to insulin in a quantity just sufficient to complex all the insulin molecules at a neutral pH.

 

Insulin glargine once daily (Option A) provides only basal insulin coverage and would necessitate additional injections of rapid-acting insulin before meals, making it less convenient.

Insulin aspart before each meal (Option C) only addresses mealtime glucose control and lacks basal coverage.

While effective, CSII (Option D) is more complex, requiring significant patient education and adherence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with painless hematuria and weight loss over the past six months. CECT reveals a 9 cm enhancing mass in the right kidney, with evidence of invasion into the renal vein. Histopathology shows cells with clear cytoplasm and a delicate network of vasculature. Which of the following is the most likely variant of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clear cell renal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological findings are indicative of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (CCRCC).

RCC Variants

Salient features

Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (CCRCC (Option C)
  • Microscopy: cells have clear cytoplasm due to the presence of abundant lipids and glycogen, surrounded by a delicate network of vasculature.

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Option B)
  • Type 1 has small basophilic cells and Type 2 is characterized by large eosinophilic cells.

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (Option A)
  • Microscopy: Characterized by large polygonal cells with prominent cell membranes and pale cytoplasm.

Collecting duct carcinoma (Option D)
  • Rare and aggressive form of RCC that arises from the collecting ducts in the renal medulla, hence centrally located.

questions.text: Renal tubular acidosis that presents with hyperkalemia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - RTA 4:

  • RTA 4 occurs secondary to diabetic nephropathy, obstructive uropathy, or chronic tubulointerstitial disease and leads to hypo-reninemic hypoaldosteronism due to damage to Distal tubule. Less aldosterone explains impaired potassium excretion and resultant hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of fatigue and exertional chest discomfort. His medical history is significant for hypertension and a family history of coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure and mild obesity. Laboratory investigations show elevated LDL cholesterol levels. Based on his risk factors and lab results, he is prescribed statin therapy. Which of the following effects may not be seen after the commencement of statin therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increase in uric acid

 

Explanation:

  • Statins (HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors) primarily lower LDL cholesterol but also have pleiotropic effects that go beyond lipid-lowering.
     
  • They typically do not increase uric acid; in fact, some studies suggest statins may lower serum uric acid.

Statins – Pharmacological Effects

Effect

Explanation

↓ LDL cholesterol

Inhibit HMG-CoA reductase → ↓ cholesterol synthesis

↓ CRP (C-reactive protein)

Anti-inflammatory effect via reduced cytokine production

Antiplatelet action

Improve endothelial function and reduce platelet aggregation

Mild anticoagulant effect

Inhibit thrombin generation and fibrinogen expression

Uric acid levels

No consistent increase; some statins may slightly reduce it

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents with severe pain during bowel movements and bright red blood on toilet paper for 2 weeks. She describes the pain as excruciating and sharp, akin to "passing glass.” Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: It mainly presents with anal itching & discharge
The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.
This condition is characterized by a thickened anal papilla and a skin tag.
The majority of cases occur in the anterior midline in women due to childbirth.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis of the given scenario is acute anal fissure.
  • Severe pain during defecation that usually subsides afterwards is a key feature of this condition

Anal Fissure

  • Most anal fissures occur in the posterior midline due to concentrated pressure during bowel movements. (Option D ruled out)
  • Anterior anal fissures are more common in women, often linked to childbirth trauma.
  • They may be acute or chronic as described below

Feature

Acute Anal Fissures

Chronic Anal Fissures

Cause

Trauma to the anal canal lining. (Passage of hard stools, prolonged diarrhoea, childbirth).

Increased anal sphincter tone converts acute to chronic fissure,

  • Elevated muscle tension reduces blood flow to the anal canal.
  • Impaired healing leads to a cycle of repeated injury.

Pain

Excruciating, sharp pain during defecation (described as "passing glass").

May be less intense than acute but can still be painful.

Duration of Pain

The pain subsides after defecation but returns with the next bowel movement. (Option B)

Persistent pain may occur, with periods of discomfort.

Bleeding

Bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping.

May also experience blood but less prominently reported.

Physical Exam

Difficult without anaesthesia due to intense pain.

An exam may be possible, with signs of irritation from the skin tag.

Additional Symptoms

Notable pain prevents physical examination; anal spasms may be present.

Presents with anal itching, discharge, or intersphincteric fistula. (Option A ruled out)

Identifying Features

Fresh, superficial tears in the anal canal.

Thickened anal papilla and skin tag present; fissure between these structures. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old student with a past history of suicide is brought to the emergency by his roommate, who found him unresponsive with an empty bottle of unknown pills. On examination, the patient is comatose with shallow breathing, hypotension, and decreased reflexes with mild pupillary dilatation. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sodium bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is  strongly suggestive of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, especially given the history of suicidal behavior.
     
  • Sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice for TCA toxicity, particularly in patients with cardiovascular instability or QRS widening on ECG.
     
  • It works by:
     
    • Alkalinizing the serum, which reduces TCA binding to sodium channels.
       
    • Increasing plasma protein binding of TCAs, thereby reducing free drug levels.
       
    • Counteracting metabolic acidosis.
       

Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) Overdose: Features and Management

Clinical Features

Management

CNS depression, coma

Airway protection

Hypotension

IV fluids, vasopressors if needed

QRS widening, arrhythmias (on ECG)

IV sodium bicarbonate

Seizures

Benzodiazepines

 

Hemodialysis (Option A):

  • Incorrect because TCAs are highly protein-bound and have a large volume of distribution, making dialysis ineffective.

Flumazenil (Option C):

  • Incorrect as this is used for benzodiazepine overdose, and is contraindicated in mixed overdoses or patients at risk of seizures, like TCA toxicity.

Naloxone (Option D):

  • Incorrect because opioid overdose presents with pinpoint pupils, respiratory depression, and unconsciousness.
  • This patient has dilated pupils and hypotension, not typical of opioid overdose.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female has been experiencing pain and stiffness in her wrists despite initial treatments. Her rheumatologist decides to start her on disease-modifying therapy (DMARDs). Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the mechanisms of action of the DMARDs?


	Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, reducing the production of DNA and RNA.
	Hydroxychloroquine inhibits T-cell activation and reduces the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
	Sulfasalazine is metabolised to 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA), which reduces inflammation of joints in rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
	Leflunomide inhibits the synthesis of purines, leading to a reduction in lymphocyte proliferation.
	Infliximab is an oral DMARD that acts by inhibiting interleukin-6.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 3, 4, and 5

 

Explanation:

  • Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, reducing the production of DNA and RNA.
  • Hydroxychloroquine inhibits T-cell activation and reduces the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • Sulfasalazine is metabolised to 5-aminosalicylic acid (effective in ulcerative colitis) and sulfapyridine (effective in RA).
  • Leflunomide inhibits the synthesis of pyrimidines by inhibiting dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase enzyme.
  • Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody (given IV) and inhibits TNF-α.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a 1-week history of worsening eye pain and redness. On examination, a constricted pupil, a hazy anterior chamber, and deposits on the back of the cornea as shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior Uveitis

 

Explanation:

  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by the presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates (KPs) on the corneal endothelium, a hazy anterior chamber (aqueous flare), and a constricted pupil.

 

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

 

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle

  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Koeppe's Nodules

 

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil

 

  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

 

Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option A):

  • Presents with dendritic corneal ulcers, not fine, grey keratic precipitates or a hazy anterior chamber.
  • It also usually does not involve a constricted pupil.

Conjunctivitis (Option B):

  • Does not cause keratic precipitates , hazy anterior chamber and a constricted pupil.

Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma (Option D):

  • Presents with a mid-dilated or fixed, mid-dilated pupil, severe pain, redness, and vision changes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about osteomyelitis is true?


	The most common site for hematogenous spread of infection in adults is the thoracolumbar spine.
	The most common organism found in patients using intravenous drugs is Salmonella typhi.
	The most common organism in children aged 1 to 4 years is Haemophilus influenza.
	The metaphysis of the distal femur and proximal tibia is the most common site of infection in children aged 2 to 6 years.
	The most common organism in sickle-cell disease is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

  • Osteomyelitis is defined as Infection and inflammation of bone and bone marrow.
  • Osteo = bone, myelo = bone marrow.
  • MC mode of spread -- Hematogenous 
  • The most common site in adults following hematogenous spread- thoracolumbar spine (Statement 1)
  • The most common age group affected children between 2 to 6 years.
  • The most common site in children is the metaphysis of distal femur and proximal tibia(Statement 4)
  • The most common organism causing Acute and chronic osteomyelitis in Adults & Children- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • The most common organism in HIV patients- MRSA
  • The most common organism in patients using intravenous drugs- Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Statement 2)
  • The most common organism in sickle-cell disease- Salmonella typhi. (Statement 5)
  • The most common organism in a child between 1 to 4 years- Haemophilus influenza. (Statement 3)
  • The most common organism in a child following upper respiratory infection- Kingella kingae

questions.text: A 45-year-old male tourist from rural Egypt presents with recurrent hematuria and lower abdominal pain. A pelvic radiograph shows a circular calcification resembling a fetal head in the pelvis with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step?

choices.text: Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova
Pelvic tuberculosis; order interferon-gamma release assay
Calcified bladder tumor; schedule CT urography

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova

 

Explanation:

  • The "fetal head in pelvis" appearance on the pelvic radiograph is pathognomonic for chronic urinary schistosomiasis.
  • Pelvic radiograph shows the classic appearance of the calcified bladder, which resembles a fetal head in the pelvis, with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter.
  • The patient's origin from rural Egypt, an endemic area for Schistosoma haematobium, further supports this diagnosis.
  • Urine microscopy for ova remains the definitive diagnostic test for schistosomiasis.

questions.text: Carlos, a 40-year-old father and avid hiker, arrives at the emergency department after being bitten by a stray dog on his forearm while out on a rural trail. The bite is deep enough that it has broken the skin, causing some bleeding. Carlos mentions he's never received a rabies vaccination before and is anxious about the possibility of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in managing Carlos’s injury?

choices.text: Clean the wound and reassure Carlos that no further treatment is necessary.
Clean the wound and administer a series of rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, without giving Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG).
Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.
Give Carlos a single dose of rabies vaccine and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) for rapid immunity.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.

Explanation:

  • Carlos’s injury is classified as a Category III exposure because the bite broke the skin and caused bleeding.
  • For Category III exposures, particularly in unvaccinated individuals, treatment requires thorough wound cleaning, a full series of rabies vaccinations, and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound to provide immediate passive immunity.

Categories of dog bite and management:

Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I

  • Touching or feeding animals

  • Licking of intact skin

  • Ensure proper hygiene

  • No treatment required

Category II

  • Nibbling on uncovered skin

  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

    • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III

  • Bites or scratches with bleeding

  • Licks on broken skin

  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.

  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

 

  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):

    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

  • Required for unvaccinated individuals

  • Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

 Simply cleaning the wound is not enough for rabies prevention after a deep bite from a potentially rabid animal. (Option A)

 RIG is required for unvaccinated individuals with significant exposure to provide immediate antibodies at the wound site (Option B)

 A single dose of rabies vaccine is not sufficient to confer lasting immunity, and the full vaccination series is needed along with RIG for adequate post-exposure prophylaxis (Option D)

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a known diagnosis of metastatic mesothelioma presents with worsening dyspnea and right-sided chest pain that is constant. Chest imaging is given below. What clinical finding is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion
Bronchial breath sounds over the effusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion

Explanation:

Egophony is a key sign of pleural effusion, particularly noted at the upper boundary of the fluid. The chest X-ray shows a right-sided pleural effusion, indicated by blunting of the costophrenic angle and increased opacity. The fluid compresses adjacent lung tissue, altering sound transmission. When the patient says "E," it may be heard as "A" over the effusion, helping to locate its upper limit.

Clinical findings of Pleural effusion

Symptoms
  • Cough, fever, and systemic signs depending on the underlying cause.
  • Pleurisy, marked by sharp, localized pain during breathing or coughing, occurs with active pleural inflammation but typically subsides once the effusion forms.
  • Constant pain, however, is often associated with malignant conditions like mesothelioma.

Physical Examination
  • Dullness on percussion. (Option A ruled out)
  • Decreased breath sounds. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diminished tactile and vocal fremitus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Egophony is most pronounced at the upper part of the effusion. (Option B)
  • Pleural Rubs can be heard during active pleurisy and may be confused with coarse crackles.

History and Diagnostic Focus
  • Comprehensive history to explore potential causes of pulmonary and systemic effusions.
  • Assess for comorbidities, medications, infectious disease indicators, and malignancy risk factors.
  • Congestive Heart Failure: Suspected with jugular venous distension, S3 heart sound, and pedal oedema.
  • Liver Cirrhosis: Considered with signs such as ascites and caput medusae.
  • Primary TB: Cachexia, cough, hemoptysis, extreme breathlessness, night sweats, evening rise in temperature.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done to assess infertility, which is given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hysterosalpingography

 

Explanation:

The above image shows hysterosalpingography with normal uterine filling and bilateral patent tubes.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG):

  • Visualising the uterine cavity & fallopian tubes by retrograde injection of radiocontrast dye to identify filling defects & blocks.
  • Timing of HSG: 
    • postmenstrual period
    • follicular phase 
    • usually D6-D11 of mesntrual cycle to avoid it during pregnancy and ensure endomtrium is thin for better visualisation

Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into the peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

Saline infusion sonography (Option A) or sonosalpingography uses ultrasound to visualise the uterus & tubes while simultaneously injecting saline (not radiocontrast dye) retrograde into the uterus.

Sonoelastography (Option C) is used to assess soft tissue stiffness.

Contrast-enhanced sonography (Option D) combines intravenous contrast injection & ultrasonographic examination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the migrating motor complex (MMC) is correct?

choices.text: The MMC occurs during periods of digestion to facilitate nutrient absorption.
The MMC is initiated by motilin and consists of three phases.
The MMC contractions migrate orally at about 10 cm/min.
The MMC occurs at intervals of approximately 50 minutes in the interdigestive state.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The MMC is initiated by motilin and consists of three phases.

 

Explanation:

Migrating Motor Complex (MMC):

  • Cyclic, recurring motility pattern occurs in the stomach and small intestine during fasting between meals.
  • The MMC occurs during fasting periods between digestion, not during active digestion.
  • Its primary role is to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal rather than facilitating nutrient absorption.
  • The hormone motilin initiates the MMC.
  • It consists of three distinct phases.
    • Quiescent period (phase I)
    • Period of irregular electrical and mechanical activity (phase II)
    • Burst of regular activity (phase III).
  • The MMC contractions migrate aborally (away from the mouth, towards the rectum) at about 5 cm/min, not orally.
  • The MMC occurs at intervals of approximately 90-100 minutes in the interdigestive state.
  • Gastric secretion, bile flow and pancreatic secretion increased during each MMC.
  • When a meal is ingested, motilin secretion is suppressed, and MMC is abolished until digestion and absorption are complete.

questions.text:
Match the following types of food sources with their respective limiting amino acids


	
		
			
			Food source
			
			
			Amino-acid
			
		
		
			
			1. Corn
			
			
			a. Lysine
			
		
		
			
			2. Wheat
			
			
			b. Methionine
			
		
		
			
			3. Nuts
			
			
			c. Tryptophan
			
		
		
			
			4. Legumes
			
			
			d. Threonine
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1:c, 2:d, 3:a, 4: b

 

Explanation:

Food item

Limiting amino acid

1. Corn/ Maize
  • Tryptophan & lysine (most common)
  • Tryptophan is a precursor of Vitamin B3 (niacin), hence its deficiency can lead to Pellagra, a condition characterized by “4 D’s” i.e., dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and in severe cases, death.

2. Cereals (Wheat, Rice)
  • Threonine & lysine
  • Rice has a slightly higher lysine content

3. Nuts
  • Lysine

4. Legumes/Pulses
  • Methionine & Cystine

 

Limiting Amino Acids: These are essential amino acids in short supply in certain foods.

  • Lysine most deficient amino acid
  • Combining vegetarian foods (e.g., rice and dal) allows proteins to complement each other, creating a complete amino acid profile.
  • Properly planned vegetarian diets with cereals, pulses, and vegetables can provide high-quality protein comparable to animal sources.

questions.text: A 25-year-old asymptomatic patient undergoes a routine lumbar spine X-ray for an unrelated complaint. The radiologist notices an incidental finding on the image. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with spina bifida occulta?

choices.text: Tuft of hair or dimple over the affected area
Often asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging
Failure of vertebral arches to fuse with intact spinal cord and meninges
Visible sac with cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Visible sac with cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect.

 

Explanation:

  • Spina bifida occulta is characterised by:
    • Failure of vertebral arches to fuse with the spinal cord and meninges remaining within the spinal canal (Option C).
    • It is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging (Option B).
    • External signs like a tuft of hair or dimple over the affected area (Option A).
  • In contrast, a visible sac containing cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect (Option D) indicates spina bifida aperta, specifically myelomeningocele, not spina bifida occulta.

questions.text: The graph below depicts an action potential. Which of the following statements correctly describes the state of ion channels at the point marked "X" on the graph?

choices.text: Na+ channels are closed; K+ channels are open.
Na+ channels are completely inactivated; K+ channels are open.
Na+ and K+ channels are open.
Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Na+ channels are inactivated; K+ channels are open.

Explanation:

  • At the peak of the action potential (point "X"), the neuron's membrane potential is briefly positive.
  • The voltage-gated Na+ channels are inactivated, at this same point, voltage-gated K+ channels are open, allowing K+ ions to flow out of the neuron.

Phase

Membrane Potential

Na+ Channels

K+ Channels

Resting State

Polarized (-70 mV)

Closed

Closed

Depolarization (Rising Phase)

Less negative, towards 0 mV.

Rapidly opening, then inactivating

Slowly opens.

Overshoot (Peak)

Briefly positive (+35 mV).

Inactivated

Open

Repolarization (Falling Phase)

Returning to negative

Inactivated

Open

After-hyperpolarization

More negative.

Closed

Slowly closing

Return to Resting State

(Option D)

Returning to -70 mV

Closed

Closed

At point "X", the peak of the action potential, voltage-gated Na+ channels are not merely closed; they are transitioning into their inactive state. (Option A)


At the peak of the action potential, the voltage-gated Na+ channels are transitioning into their inactive state. (Option C)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with gradual central vision loss in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals concentric rings of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea, creating a characteristic appearance. The image showing the appearance is given below:



 

Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic central serous chorioretinopathy

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows the characteristic appearance of Bull's eye maculopathy, a retinal disorder characterised by concentric rings of RPE atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea, creating an appearance resembling a bull's eye target.
  • While chronic central serous chorioretinopathy can cause retinal pigment epithelium changes, it typically does not present with the characteristic bull's eye maculopathy appearance.

 

Etiological causes of bull’s eye maculopathy include:

  • Chloroquine maculopathy (Option C)
  • Hydroxychloroquine (Option A)
  • Cone dystrophy (Option B)
  • Battens disease

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of self-harm, chronic emptiness, and unstable relationships often alternates between idealizing and devaluing others. What defense mechanism is most commonly observed in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Splitting

Explanation:

  • Splitting is a common defense mechanism in borderline personality disorder, where individuals view people or situations as either all good or all bad, contributing to their unstable relationships.

 

BORDERLINE PERSONALITY DISORDER:

 

General Characteristics

  • More common in females than in males.
  • Persons with BPD are often in a state of crisis, with frequent mood swings, shifting from being argumentative to depressed, and later feeling numb.
  • They can experience short-lived psychotic episodes and their behavior is highly unpredictable,

 

Self-Destructive Behaviors

  • Repetitive self-destructive acts such as wrist slashing or self-mutilation, often to elicit help from others, express anger, or numb overwhelming emotions.

 

Interpersonal Relationships

  • Individuals with BPD have tumultuous interpersonal relationships, feeling both dependent on others and hostile toward them when frustrated.
  • They cannot tolerate being alone and prefer companionship, even in unhealthy relationships.

 

Identity and Emotional Experience

  • Chronic feelings of emptiness, boredom, and a lack of a consistent sense of identity (identity diffusion) are common, with some complaining of feeling depressed despite fluctuating moods.

 

Distorted Relationships

  • Relationships are distorted, with others seen as either "all good" or "all bad" due to splitting, leading to idealization or devaluation of people.

 

Defense Mechanism

  • Projective identification is a common defense mechanism, where patients project unacceptable aspects of themselves onto others, inducing them to play the projected role.

 

Treatment

  • Dialectical behaviour therapy.
  • Mentalization based therapy.
  • Transference: Focussed Psychotherapy.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Antipsychotics, antidepressants, mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.

 

Sublimation (Option A) is a mature defense mechanism where individuals redirect unacceptable impulses or emotions into socially acceptable behaviors or activities.

Rationalization (Option C) involves explaining away or justifying behaviors or feelings to make them seem more acceptable or less distressing.

Displacement (Option D) involves shifting emotions from a threatening target to a safer one, such as expressing anger toward a friend instead of an authority figure.

questions.text: A scientist observes the process of DNA replication in a human stem cell. He takes a sample of double-stranded DNA from the cell and studies it separately. He finds that the total amount of adenine in the sample is 24%. From the given information, what percentage of cytosine is present in the sample?
questions.solution:
• According to Chargaff’s Rule, DNA follows base-pairing where:
    • Adenine (A) pairs with Thymine (T)
    • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G)
  • Given Adenine (A) = 24%, this means Thymine (T) = 24% as well.
  • The total percentage of A + T = 24% + 24% = 48%.
  • Since DNA is double-stranded, the remaining percentage must be from Cytosine (C) and Guanine (G).
    • C + G = 100% - 48% = 52%.
    • As C and G are equal in amount, we divide:
      C = G = 52% ÷ 2 = 26%.

 

.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with persistent abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months. He reports no significant past medical history and denies any changes in bowel habits. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a well-circumscribed mass in the pancreas. Laboratory tests show elevated serum glucose levels but normal levels of other pancreatic hormones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-functioning pancreatic NET

Explanation:

Non-functioning pancreatic NET does not secrete hormones and often remains asymptomatic until it causes anatomic symptoms like abdominal pain and weight loss. Elevated serum glucose levels suggest glucose intolerance, ruling out insulinoma due to a lack of excessive insulin. Normal levels of other pancreatic hormones further support this diagnosis.

Functioning PNET

Non-functioning PNET (Option C)
  • Associated with symptoms due to hormone secretion.
  • The most common are insulinomas.

 
  • No hormone secretion.
  • The majority of pancreatic NETs (about 80%) are nonfunctional.
  • Often clinically silent until they cause anatomic symptoms.
  • Typically diagnosed incidentally or when symptoms like abdominal pain or weight loss occur.
  • Usually more advanced when found (metastasized)


 

Functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour

Tumor

Hormone

Symptoms/signs

Insulinoma        (Option A)

Insulin

Hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma        (Option B)

Glucagon

Peptic ulcer, diarrhoea, GERD

Somatostatinoma

Somatostatin

Diarrhea, diabetes, hypochlorhydria, cholelithiasis.

Glucagonoma     (Option D)

Glucagon

Necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, depression

VIPoma

Vasoactive intestinal peptide

Watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty walking. His parents report a family history of similar symptoms. A detailed history was obtained, and a pedigree analysis was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis and the inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D) Duchenne muscular dystrophy, X-linked recessive
 

EXPLANATION:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease.

 

X-linked recessive disorders:

Males are affected by the disease.

Examples of X-linked recessive disorders:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who has been treated for glaucoma comes with complaints of muscle weakness, fatigue, and palpitations. Laboratory tests reveal significant hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which class of diuretics is most likely responsible for these symptoms, considering the maximum loss of potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

Explanation :

  • The clinical scenario suggests hypokalemia, and his ABG shows metabolic acidosis, which suggests the use of a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, which is commonly used in glaucoma.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor causes maximum hypokalemia and also produces metabolic acidosis

Diuretics causing maximum potassium loss:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors cause the most potassium loss and cause metabolic acidosis, followed by thiazides (Option B), loop diuretics (Option A), and osmotic diuretics (Option C). Metabolic alkalosis is seen with thiazides and loops

Diuretics cause maximum sodium loss:

  • Loop diuretics lead to the greatest sodium loss, followed by thiazides, osmotic diuretics, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, and potassium-sparing diuretics.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity.



Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

choices.text: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.
Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.
Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plan for Phacoemulsification.

Explanation:

Gradual, progressive loss of vision along with improvement in near vision (referred to as “second sight”), combined with characteristic slit-lamp findings, is suggestive of Nuclear Cataract, for which phacoemulsification is the treatment of choice.

  • Management:
    • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
    • Cataract surgeries:
      • ICCE (not preferred now)
      • ECCE
      • SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
      • Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
    • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months (Option A) would not address the cataract directly and would not improve the visual acuity.

Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months (Option B): The use of topical corticosteroids after cataract surgery reduces postoperative noninfectious inflammation but it is not used as the treatment for nuclear cataract.

Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses (Option D): Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses are indicated for early-stage keratoconus with astigmatism.

questions.text:
A research student is studying cytokine profiles of different T helper cell subsets. In the experiment, naive CD4+ T cells were activated and differentiated into different subsets.

Which of the following correctly matches the T helper cell subset with its primary cytokine secretion pattern and major function?

 


	
		
			
			a. TH-1
			
			
			1. IL-17, IL-22
			
			
			x. Recruit neutrophils
			
		
		
			
			b. TH-2
			
			
			2. IFN-γ
			
			
			y. Promote antibody production
			
		
		
			
			c. TH-17
			
			
			3. IL-4, IL-5, IL-13
			
			
			z. Enhance macrophage activation
questions.solution:
Different T helper cell subsets have distinct cytokine profiles and functions:

 

T Helper Subset

Key Cytokines

Major Functions

Role in Immunity

TH1 Cells

• IL-2

• IFN-γ

• TNF-β

• Activate macrophages

• Enhance cell-mediated immunity

• Stimulate cytotoxic T cells

• Protection against intracellular pathogens

• Mediate delayed-type hypersensitivity

TH2 Cells

• IL-6

• IL-10

• IL-13

• Protection at mucosal surfaces

• Involved in autoimmune diseases

• Contribute to inflammatory conditions

questions.text: A 23-year-old female visited the clinician with a solitary thyroid nodule and was advised for thyroid function tests where Tsh level is 27.3mU/L, T3 is 1.24 ng/ml, and T4 is 4.87 microgram/ml. Which of the following manifestations is true regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Weight gain

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s thyroid function tests show elevated TSH with normal T3 and T4 levels, indicating primary hypothyroidism.
  • Weight Gain is consistent with hypothyroidism due to reduced metabolic rate.
  • Heat Intolerance (Option A), Tachycardia (Option B), and Diarrhea (Option C) are more common in hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the clinic with noticeable cognitive decline. She is diagnosed with Dementia with Lewy Bodies. Which of the following is not a core feature of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Systematized delusions

 

Explanation:

While delusions can occur in DLB, systematized delusions (fixed false beliefs that are well organized) are not considered a core feature of the condition, rather are considered a supporting feature.

  • DLB primarily features hallucinations, particularly visual ones, rather than structured delusions.

 

Dementia with Lewy Bodies

  • Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cognitive decline sufficient to interfere with social or occupational functioning.
  • Early symptoms may include difficulties with attention, fronto-subcortical skills, and visuospatial ability, rather than prominent memory issues.

 

Clinical Features:

Probable DLB requires two or more core symptoms, while possible DLB requires at least one.

Core Features

Supporting Features
  • Fluctuating levels of attention and alertness (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations (Option B ruled out)
  • Parkinsonian features (e.g., cogwheeling, bradykinesia, resting tremor) (Option D ruled out)
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Repeated falls
  • Syncope
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics
  • Systematized delusions (Option C)
  • Hallucinations in other modalities (e.g., auditory, tactile)

 

Differences in features of LBD and PD:

Feature

Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)

Parkinson's Disease (PD)

Onset of Symptoms

Cognitive and psychiatric symptoms appear early; motor symptoms develop later.

Primarily motor symptoms appear first (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors).

Visual Hallucinations

Common and can occur early.

Less common initially; may occur later, often due to treatment.

Fluctuations in Attention

Fluctuations in alertness and attention are characteristic.

Fluctuations are primarily related to medication cycles.

Response to Medications

Poor response to dopaminergic medications; risk of worsening psychiatric symptoms.

Generally improves with dopaminergic medications (e.g., levodopa).

Sleep Disturbances

REM sleep behavior disorder is common and can precede cognitive symptoms.

REM sleep behavior disorder may occur but is primarily linked to motor symptoms.

Progression

Rapid progression of cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Gradual progression of motor symptoms, with cognitive decline developing later.

 

Pathology:

  • Lewy body disease presents clinically similarly to Alzheimer’s disease but is marked by hallucinations, parkinsonian features, and extrapyramidal signs.
  • Lewy bodies, which are abnormal accumulations of α-synuclein aggregates, are found in the cerebral cortex and substantia nigra.
  • In cases where Lewy body pathology coexists with Alzheimer’s, the amygdala is often the only affected region.
  • Patients with Lewy body dementia may exhibit Capgras syndrome (reduplicative paramnesia), highlighting the complex nature of their symptoms.

Lewy bodies

questions.text: Patient with upper GI bleeding and pedal oedema is found to have ‘cerebriform appearance of stomach mucosa’ on UGI endoscopy. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Menetrier disease

  • Menetrier disease is a rare hypertrophic gastropathy characterized by enlarged, thickened gastric folds with a characteristic cerebriform /brain-like convoluted appearance on endoscopy.
  • The disease features foveolar hyperplasia (proliferation of mucus-secreting cells), leading to thickened gastric folds visible endoscopically with this distinctive appearance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe pain and swelling in his right calf following an intense workout session two days ago. Laboratory tests, including measurements of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzymes, are ordered. Which LDH isoenzyme is most indicative of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) LDH-5

Explanation:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme involved in converting lactate to pyruvate during anaerobic glycolysis.
  • It consists of four subunits, forming five different isoenzymes that vary in tissue distribution.
  • LDH-5, primarily found in skeletal muscle and liver, serves as a biomarker and typically indicates skeletal muscle damage, seen in muscle injury, rhabdomyolysis, or intense physical exertion.

 

Isoenzyme

Tissue/Organ

Clinical Use

LDH-1(Option A)

Heart

Elevated levels can indicate myocardial infarction or other tissue damage.

LDH-2 (Option B)

Reticuloendothelial system

Elevated levels can suggest tissue damage or disease.

LDH-3 (Option C)

Lungs

Elevated levels can be associated with lung conditions.

LDH-4

Kidneys and placenta

Elevated levels may indicate kidney or placental issues.

LDH-5

Liver and skeletal muscle

Elevated levels can be related to liver or muscle damage.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe abdominal pain and per-vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender, the pulse rate is 110 bpm, and BP is 90/60 mm Hg. Fetal heart sounds are absent. What grade of abruptio placentae is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3

 

Explanation:

The patient has per-vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain (uterine tenderness), haemodynamic instability (increased pulse rate and hypotension), and absent fetal heart sounds. It indicates grade 3 abruptio placentae.

 

Abruptio placentae- A form of antepartum haemorrhage where bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

 

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the OPD with severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right knee. Examination reveals tender swelling and redness at the base of the right 1st toe. Serum urate levels are normal, but arthrocentesis reveals negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarised light. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this acute attack?
questions.solution:
Oral colchicine is the drug of choice for the management of acute gout attacks.

 

Management of acute gout attack

Colchicine

(Option B)
  • Microtubule inhibitor, which prevents microtubule assembly in neutrophils, thus reducing inflammation.
  • Colchicine disrupts the function of the cytoskeleton by inhibiting the polymerization of beta-tubulin into microtubules.
  • This prevents the formation and function of microtubules, which are essential for various cellular processes.
  • By disrupting microtubule formation, colchicine inhibits the activation, degranulation, and migration of neutrophils, which are key players in the inflammatory response. This reduces the inflammatory cascade associated with conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine does not prevent phagocytosis of uric acid crystals, but it inhibits the release of an inflammatory glycoprotein from phagocytes. This contributes to its anti-inflammatory action in conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine blocks metaphase in dividing cells by disrupting mitotic spindle formation.
  • DOC for acute attacks of gout.
  • Dose: 0.6 mg TID - introduced after 2-3 days when swelling reduces.
  • Side effects: Nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

NSAIDs
  • It is effective when used early in an attack of gout.
  • Indomethacin 25-50 mg TID / Naproxen 500 mg BID / Ibuprofen 800 mg TID
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment

Glucocorticoids

(Option C)
  • It can be used as an intramuscular injection for multi-articular involvement or intra-articular injection for mono-articular involvement, or orally.
  • Safe to use in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

Other treatments

  • Ice therapy: Reduces swelling and inflammation
  • Canakinumab (IL-1 β inhibitor) (Option A)
  • Anakinra: Reserved for resistant cases

Urate lowering agents

  • Drugs: Allopurinol, Febuoxostat, Probenecid and Pegloticase
  • Contraindicated in acute attacks.
  • Rapidly reduces serum urate level, which causes the dissolution of organised monosodium urate crystals.
  • Causes an inflammatory reaction towards the shed crystals.

 

Allopurinol (Option D) is a urate-lowering agent that inhibits xanthine oxidase, reducing urate production from hypoxanthine and xanthine. It is not recommended during active gout flares, as it can exacerbate the attack. While it lowers serum urate levels and promotes the dissolution of monosodium urate crystals, this may trigger an inflammatory reaction to the released crystals.

questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with fever, cough, and respiratory distress. CT  chest is perfomed. Which of the following investigations would be most specific to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Lung histology shows fungal septate hyphae with branching at 45 degrees

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactomannan antigen test from respiratory samples

 

Explanation:

  • HRCT chest in immunocompromised patient shows air crescent sign (right lung)  and Halo sign  (posterior segment of the left lower lobe, abutting the vertebral body) seen in Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Galactomannan antigen test on BAL is a sensitive and specific biomarker for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis.It detects a polysaccharide component of the Aspergillus cell wall that is released during active infection.
  • Beta-1,3-D-glucan is more panfungal, so it's helpful in screening but less specific.
  • The BACTEC™ MGIT 960 system is an automated, rapid culture system used primarily for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and other mycobacteria from clinical specimens. 
  • Histological examination in invasive aspergillosis reveals hyphae, which are hyaline, narrow, septate, and branch at 45°. It is diagnostic in only 10-30% cases

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presented with headache, blurring of vision, weakness and loss of balance. His radiological investigations suggested hydrocephalus and pheochromocytoma. A tumour is detected whose radiograph is given below. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) VHL syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The above features suggest Hemangioblastoma and the associated genetic disorder is VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome.
  • Hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular tumour of the central nervous system associated with VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome, which consists of the following,
    • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
    • Retinal hemangioma
    • RCC(Renal Cell Carcinoma)
    • Renal cyst
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Epididymal/ broad ligament cyst adenoma
    • Endolymphatic sac tumours
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

 

  • MRI in hemangioblastoma shows a cystic tumour with a non-enhancing wall and enhancing mural nodule, which is managed by surgical resection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the clinic with foul-smelling diarrhoea and abdominal cramps for the past week. A stool examination revealed giardia cysts. After starting appropriate treatment, she returned a few days later, complaining of severe nausea, vomiting, headaches, and flushing after the farewell party. Which of the following is not a side effect associated with the medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tendon rupture

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical findings of the patient (foul-smelling stool, abdominal cramps), along with the stool examination, indicate giardiasis which is most likely treated with metronidazole experienced a disulfiram-like reaction after drinking alcohol during the party.
  • Common side effects include a metallic taste, neurotoxicity (peripheral neuropathy), and dark urine, while tendon rupture is a side effect of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin).

Adverse effects of Metronidazole

Side effects
  • Metallic taste, intensely bitter (Option B)
  • Headache, nausea, dry mouth (most common)
  • Vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal distress
  • Dysuria, cystitis, and a sense of pelvic pressure
  • Dizziness, vertigo,
  • Neurotoxicity: Peripheral neuropathy, numbness, paresthesias, ataxia (Option C)
  • Brown color urine (Option A)
  • Urticaria, flushing, and pruritus ( rare cause of Stevens-Johnson syndrome)

Drug Interaction
  • Inhibitor of CYP enzymes
  • Disulfiram-like effect: abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, headache or psychosis with alcoholic beverages during or within 3 days of therapy.
  • Precipitate lithium toxicity
  • Prothrombin time prolongation with warfarin (anticoagulant).

Contraindications
  • CNS diseases
  • Severe hepatic disease
  • First trimester of pregnancy

questions.text: According to the given image of heme synthesis, which of the following statements is incorrect?

The enzyme involved in step a) is Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
4 molecules of CO2 are liberated at step a)
Ferrochelatase is the enzyme involved in step d)

Correct Answer: A. Steps c and d occur in Mitochondria, while steps a and b occur in the cytosol.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Stool cultures reveal the presence of a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that is oxidase-negative, ferments glucose, and reduces nitrate to nitrite. Which of the following bacteria is most likely the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Escherichia coli

 

Explanation:

E. coli is a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that ferments glucose and is oxidase-negative. It can reduce nitrate to nitrite and is a common cause of gastrointestinal infections, particularly diarrhea, in adults. Given the symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, along with the culture results, E. coli is the most likely causative agent.

 

Edwards-Ewing Classification of the Enterobacteriaceae Family

Tribes and Genera:

Tribe

Genus

Escherichiae

Escherichia (Option A), Shigella

Edwardsiellae

Edwardsiella

Salmonellae

Salmonella

Citrobacteriaceae

Citrobacter

Klebsielleae

Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Serratia, Hafnia, Pantoea

Proteae

Proteus, Providencia, Morganella

Yersinieae

Yersinia

Erwinieae

Erwinia

 

Characteristics of the Enterobacteriaceae Family (Option A)

  • Microscopy:
    • Gram-negative bacilli, appearing as rod-shaped bacteria.
    • Non-sporing, indicating they do not form spores for survival in harsh environments.
  • Oxygen Requirements:
    • Aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, meaning they can grow in the presence or absence of oxygen, providing them with versatility in various environments.
  • Motility:
    • Most members are motile due to peritrichous flagella, which are flagella distributed all over the surface of the bacteria.
    • Notable non-motile genera include Shigella and Klebsiella, which lack flagella.
  • Biochemical Properties:
    • Ferments glucose, producing both gas and acid as byproducts, a characteristic that can be useful in distinguishing these bacteria in the lab.
    • Reduces nitrates to nitrites, an important metabolic process that aids in the identification of specific species.
    • Produces catalase, which helps break down hydrogen peroxide, protecting the bacteria from oxidative damage.
    • Does not produce oxidase, distinguishing it from other similar families of bacteria.

 

Clostridium difficile (Option B): Clostridium difficile is gram-positive bacillus.

 

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): Staphylococcus aureus is gram-positive cocci.


Vibrio cholerae (Option D): Vibrio cholerae is gram-negative curved bacilli with polar flagellum.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female with a history of cholelithiasis presents with acute abdominal pain, vomiting, and signs of bowel obstruction. O/E, she has abdominal distension and high-pitched bowel sounds. A radiograph shows pneumobilia and a calcified gallstone in the right lower quadrant. CT confirms an abnormal gallbladder with air and fluid accumulation. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Conservative management with IV fluids and antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Enterolithotomy

 

Explanation:

Given the clinical scenario with Rigler's triad (small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and ectopic gallstone) and the corresponding imaging findings, the most likely diagnosis is gallstone ileus. The optimal initial surgical management is enterolithotomy, which effectively relieves the intestinal obstruction by removing the impacted gallstone.


 

Effects and Complications of Gallstones:

 

Gallbladder

Common bile duct and pancreas

Small intestine
  • Acute cholecystitis
  • Chronic cholecystitis
  • Mucocele
  • Empyema
  • Gangrene
  • Perforation
  • Carcinoma gallbladder
  • CBD stones
  • Biliary obstruction (Jaundice)
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Mirizzi syndrome

Gallstone ileus leading to intestinal obstruction

 

Gallstone Ileus

  • Acute cholecystitis→ erosion of inflamed tissues → Formation of a cholecystointestinal fistula→ Gallstone ileus
  • Small gallstones typically pass through the intestines, but stones 2–5 cm in size can become impacted, usually in the terminal ileum or at the ileocecal valve.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction.
  • Signs of obstruction include dehydration, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.

Diagnosis:

  • Plain Abdominal Radiograph:
    • Partial or complete intestinal obstruction
    • Pneumobilia or contrast material in the biliary tree
    • Calcified gallstone with position changes on serial films (tumbling sign)
  • CT Scan:
    • Superior sensitivity (up to 93%)
    • Shows abnormal gallbladder with air, air-fluid level, or fluid accumulation with an irregular wall

Management:

  • Management of intestinal obstruction
  • Enterolithotomy: The most common surgical procedure
    • A longitudinal incision on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of impaction
    • Gallstone is brought to a non-edematous bowel segment by gentle manipulation and extraction.
  • Cholecystoenteric fistula resection only if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus

Cholecystectomy and fistula repair (Option A): While important, this is not the initial step due to the patient's unstable condition and intestinal obstruction.

Endoscopic removal of the gallstone (Option B): Not feasible for this condition due to the intestinal obstruction.

Conservative management with IV fluids and antibiotics (Option D): Not sufficient for resolving the mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hymenolepis nana

 

Explanation:

This is an egg of Hyenopelsis nana.

 

 

  • Size: 30–50 μm in diameter.
  • Shape: Oval or spherical with a thin shell.
  • Inner membrane/embryophore: Characterized by polar filaments extending into the space between the inner and outer shell.
  • Embryo: Contains an oncosphere with three pairs of hooklets.

questions.text:
Match the following images of forceps with their names.


	
		
			
			1.

			
			
			
			a. Simpson forceps
			
		
		
			
			2.

			
			
			
			b. Piper forceps
			
		
		
			
			3.

			
			
			
			c. Wrigley's forceps
			
		
		
			
			4.​​​​​​​

			
			
			
			d. Kielland forceps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with dark-coloured urine and puffiness around his eyes following a recent sore throat and skin infection. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine, hematuria, and proteinuria. Renal biopsy image is given below. Which condition is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Explanation:

Pathological findings in PSGN

Grossly

Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance).

Light microscopy

Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.

 

 

Condition

Findings in microscopy

IgA Nephropathy (Option A)

Mesangial deposition of IgA

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option B)

Mesangial & subendothelial immune deposits are seen

Alport Syndrome (Option D)

Basket Weave Appearance of GBM

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman reports bilateral itching, redness, and watery discharge that worsens in spring. Examination revealed mild conjunctival congestion with small papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Allergic Conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

  • Given the seasonal pattern of symptoms, bilateral itching, watery discharge, mild conjunctival congestion, and the presence of small papillae point toward the diagnosis of allergic conjunctivitis.

 

Conjunctival inflammatory reactions can be in the form of:

Follicles

Papillae

Granuloma

  • Yellowish-white, round elevations, 1-2 mm in diameter, due to lymphocyte aggregations in the subepithelial adenoid layer.
  • Conjunctiva of newborns cannot produce follicles until 2-3 months of age.
  • Hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.
  • Fleshy, sessile, or pedunculated lesions with inflammatory tissue.
  • May or may not be truly granulomatous.
  • Resulting from chronic local irritation, such as foreign bodies.

 

Viral Conjunctivitis (Option A) typically presents with watery discharge and moderate conjunctival congestion.

  • It is often associated with follicles rather than papillae, and a seasonal pattern is less likely than that of allergic conjunctivitis.

 

Bacterial Conjunctivitis (Option C) is characterized by purulent discharge and marked conjunctival congestion.

  • While bacterial conjunctivitis can sometimes present with papillae, these are not usually as prominent or marked as those in allergic conjunctivitis.

 

Chlamydial Conjunctivitis (Option D) typically presents with mucopurulent discharge and moderate conjunctival congestion.

  • It is often associated with follicles, and papillae may or may not be present.
  • The lack of prominent papillae and specific seasonal patterns make it less likely than allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Given below is the action potential of a cardiac muscle fiber. Which of the following gives rise to Phase 2 depicted in the image?

choices.text: Closure of Na+ channels and opening of K+ channel
Closure of the Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux
Opening of slow L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels and efflux of K+ though rectifier channels.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Opening of slow L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels and efflux of K+ though rectifier channels

 

Explanation:

The given prolonged plateau (phase 2) is due to a slower but prolonged opening of voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channels and efflux of Potassium through rectifier channels.

 

 

 

PHASES

OPENING AND CLOSURE OF CHANNELS

Phase 0- Depolarization

Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels(Option C)

Phase 1- Initial rapid repolarization

Closure of Na+ channels

Opening of K+ channel (Option A)

Phase 2- Plateau phase

Slower but prolonged opening of L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels 

K+ channel also remains open.

Phase 3- Late rapid repolarization

Closure of the Ca2+ channels 

Slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux (Option B)

Phase 4- Baseline

Resting Membrane Potential About −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance. Which substrate accumulates in Gaucher's disease due to the deficient enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucosylceramide

 

Explanation:

  • Gaucher’s disease → deficiency of β-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase) → accumulation of glucosylceramide.

  • Features: hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, bone pain, “wrinkled paper” macrophages.

Takeaway:
Gaucher’s = β-glucosidase deficiency → glucosylceramide accumulation.

  • Sphingomyelin (Option A) → Niemann-Pick

  • Ganglioside (Option C) → Tay-Sachs

  • Ceramide (Option D)→ Farber disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with multiple light-coloured patches on his chest and back, which are more noticeable after sun exposure. The lesions are asymptomatic but have not resolved with moisturizers. An image of the Microscopic examination of skin scrapings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Tinea versicolor

 

Explanation:

Tinea versicolor is caused by Malassezia furfur and presents as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macular lesions, typically on the chest, back, or upper limbs. It is asymptomatic and diagnosed by finding yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments on microscopy.

 

Tinea Versicolor (Pityriasis Versicolor)

  • A superficial fungal infection of the stratum corneum (outer skin layer)
  • Mostly asymptomatic but may lead to visible skin discolouration
  • Prevalent in tropical climates, commonly affecting young adults
  • Causative agent: Malassezia furfur (previously called Pityrosporum orbiculare)
  • Appearance:
    • Presents as discrete or confluent macular lesions
    • Affected areas show pigmentation changes (hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation)
  • Commonly affected sites:
    • Chest, abdomen, upper limbs, and back

 

Diagnostic Tools:

Test/Tool

Findings

Microscopy (Skin Scrapings)

Abundant yeast cells and short, branched filaments (yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments):

Tinea versicolor KOH." data-author="" data-hash="10095" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RrVjSljkSpVrKoq2sYTO1744469150.png" />

Spaghetti and meatball appearance under KOH microscopy:

 

Culture

Grown on Sabouraud agar with an olive oil overlay.

Versicolor SDA" data-author="" data-hash="10097" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/rHhlfhaSGBz1aVg5YagT1744469378.png" />

Wood’s Lamp Exam

Infected areas fluoresce golden-yellow under UV light.

Versicolor Wood’s Lamp " data-author="" data-hash="10098" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/EVtP4p0OtNCrspsH4Gs61744469541.jpg" />

versicolor on face" data-author="" data-hash="10099" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/mHm11m1bRBeDqREyedFM1744469645.png" />

 

Tinea corporis (Option A): A dermatophyte infection characterized by annular, scaly lesions with raised borders. This option is incorrect.

 

Tinea nigra (Option B): Caused by Hortaea werneckii and characterized by black or brown macular lesions. This option is incorrect.

Candidiasis (Option D): Presents as erythematous plaques or white patches in moist areas (like skin folds) or mucosal surfaces (oral thrush, vaginal candidiasis). This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 28 weeks gestation, conceived via in vitro fertilization (IVF) is now carrying dichorionic-diamniotic twins. She reports increasing discomfort and shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. Which of the following is the least likely complication in her pregnancy ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome .

Explanation:

Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) is a complication specific to monochorionic twins (not DCDA) due to sharing of placenta & in those with problematic deep arterio-venous connections between the placentas. Such connections are more often encountered in MCDA twins rather than MCMA twins.

Maternal Complications can be divided into 3 stages:

  • Pregnancy
  • Labor
  • Puerperium

 

Pregnancy

Labor

Puerperium
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Anemia
  • PIH and pre-eclampsia
  • Polyhydramnios/ oligohydramnios
  • Preterm labor
  • Malpresentation
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Mechanical distress (dyspnea, palpitation)
  • Prolonged labor
  • Operative interference
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Infection
  • Lactation failure

 

Preterm labor (Option B ) occurs frequently (in 50% of cases) in twin pregnancies, with twins typically being delivered around 37 weeks gestation on average. The causes include excessive stretching of the uterus, increased amniotic fluid (hydramnios), and premature rupture of membranes

 

Pre-eclampsia (Option C): The risk is three times higher in twin pregnancies, possibly due to increased exposure to an excess of chorionic villi 

 

Malpresentation (Option D) is more frequent in twins compared to single pregnancies. Approximately 70% of the time, the first baby presents headfirst (vertex), and in 50% of cases, both babies present headfirst. Therefore, malpresentation is more commonly observed in the second baby

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. The patient also reports difficulty swallowing, with no complaints of weight loss, fatigue, or heat intolerance. An excisional biopsy reveals >75% of the following characteristic cells. Which genetic mutation is most commonly associated with this type of thyroid tumour?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) RAS

 

Explanation:

The above image shows cells with abundant pinkish eosinophilic cytoplasm and small regular nuclei, suggesting Hurthle cells. The presence of >75% of these cells indicates a Hurthle cell adenoma, a rare thyroid neoplasm of follicular cell origin associated with RAS mutation.

  • Hurthle cell adenomas are variants of follicular adenoma, and the presence of more than 75% of Hurthle cells is a key diagnostic feature.

Thyroid Malignancy

Mutations/Genetic Alterations

Follicular Thyroid Adenoma

(Benign Condition)
  • RAS

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC)
  • BRAF V600E
  • RET/PTC rearrangements

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC)
  • RAS
  • PAX8-PPARγ rearrangements
  • PIK3CA

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • RET

Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma (ATC)
  • TP53

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, distension, and a large pelvic mass accompanied by ascites. Elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein levels are detected. Surgical resection of the mass reveals histopathological findings depicted in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?

 


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endodermal sinus tumour

 

Explanation:

Given clinical presentation of 16 year old female with abdominal pain and ascites along with elevated serum AFP and HPE showing shiller duval bodies points towards Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor.

Shiller duval bodies: It is characterized by a central blood vessel surrounded by a row of tumor cells, a clear space, and another outer row of tumor cells.

Classification of Germ cell tumours:

Tumour type

Histological feature

Endodermal Sinus Tumour
  • Presence of Schiller-Duval bodies.

 

 

Dysgerminoma
  • ‘Fried egg appearance’ (large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei).
  • Lymphocytic infiltration in the fibrous septa.

 

Choriocarcinoma
  • Consists of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts.
  • It may show haemorrhage and necrosis.

 

 

Teratoma
  • They comprise tissues from all three germ cell layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), such as skin, hair,teeth, and neural tissue.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for her routine prenatal check-up. She is currently 11 weeks pregnant and feeling anxious about her pregnancy due to her age and the risk of chromosomal abnormalities associated with it. During a fetal aneuploidy screening, risk of Trisomy 21 is increased. What would be the levels of Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) and Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A) in Trisomy 21?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increased hCG and Decreased PAPP-A.

Explanation:

Trisomy 21 is characterized by increased hCG and decreased PAPP-A.

 

First Trimester Aneuploidy screening includes:

  • Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Nuchal Translucency (NT) on UltraSonoGram (USG)

 

Increased NT is more commonly associated with cardiac abnormalities than trisomies. Therefore, a fetal echocardiogram is recommended when NT measurement is >3.5 mm.
 

Trisomy 18 and 13 are characterized by decreased hCG and decreased PAPP-A. (Option B ruled out).

questions.text:
In a chest X-ray given below, the inferior border of the heart is primarily contributed by which structure?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Right Ventricle

 

Explanation:

The right ventricle forms the majority of the inferior border of the heart in a normal CXR, extending from the inferior vena cava (IVC) to the apex of the heart.

Borders of the Heart

  • Right Border:
    • Formed by the right atrium.
    • Extends from the opening of the superior vena cava (SVC) to the inferior vena cava (IVC).
  • Left Border:
    • Formed mainly by the left ventricle.
    • Partly by the left auricle.
    • Extends from the left auricle to the apex of the heart.
  • Inferior Border:
    • Formed by the right ventricle.
    • Partly by the right atrium and left ventricle(near apex).
