    • Extends from the opening of the IVC to the apex of the heart.
  • Upper Border:
    • Formed mainly by the left atrium.
    • Partly by the right atrium.
    • Also by the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk.

questions.text:
Which among the given statements is wrong regarding resuscitation of newborn?

 

a) The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg

b) Correct order of suction: mouth followed by nose.

c) The recommended pressure should never exceed >80 mmHg

d) Correct order of suction: nose followed by mouth
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) c & d are wrong

 

Explanations:

Suction of airways:

  • The correct order of suction: is mouth followed by nose.
  • When suctioning the nose, vagal stimulation may induce the baby to take a deep breath, potentially resulting in aspiration, if oral secretions are present.
  • The recommended pressure of suction is 80 mmHg
  • It should never exceed >100 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Nocardia and Actinomyces is false?

choices.text: Actinomyces infections are endogenous, whereas Nocardia infections are exogenous.
Actinomyces is nonacid-fast, while Nocardia is partially acid-fast.
Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections.
Nocardia is an obligate aerobe, whereas Actinomyces is anaerobic.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections.

 

Explanation:

Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Actinomyces, whereas Nocardia is treated with cotrimoxazole.


 

Features

Actinomycetes

Nocardia

Acid-fastness

(Option B ruled out)

Nonacid-fast

Partially acid-fast

O2 Requirement

(Option D ruled out)

Anaerobe

Obligate aerobe

Habitat

(Option A ruled out)
  • Found as oral flora
  • Infections occur endogenously
  • The usual habitat is the soil
  • Infections occur exogenously

Risk factors

Immunocompetent also

Usually only in immunocompromised

Clinical forms

Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others.

Pulmonary, CNS forms, Actinomycetoma

Granules

Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance)
  • Granules are soft and lobulated and also show a sun-ray appearance
  • Commonly found in mycetoma, rare in other conditions

Culture
  • Spidery molar teeth colony in solid media
  • Fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium
  • Colonies are creamy, wrinkled, and pink Isolation is done in
  • Selective media
  • Paraffin bait technique
  • LJ medium

Treatment

(Option C)

Penicillin

Cotrimoxazole

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the orthopedic OPD with a four-month history of left knee pain, which worsens with activity and at night. She has had episodes of low-grade fever and fatigue but denies any recent trauma. Upon physical examination, the left knee has limited range of motion and noticeable soft-tissue swelling. An image of the X-ray of the left knee joint is shown below. What is Phemister’s triad, and how does it relate to this case?

choices.text: A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis
A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis
A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma
A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis

 

Explanation: Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific.

X-ray findings:

  • Characteristic signs are soft-tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis.
  • Bone ends appear ‘washed-out,’ and the articular space narrows.
  • In children, epiphyses may enlarge due to prolonged hyperemia.
  • Subarticular bone erosion occurs on both sides, indicating synovial inflammation.
  • Cystic lesions may appear in adjacent bone ends.
  • Little to no periosteal reaction, unlike a pyogenic infection, where reactive periosteal new bone formation is an important feature.
  • Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific. (Option B)

 

A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis (Option A): Septic arthritis typically presents with sudden onset of joint pain, swelling, and fever, often with systemic signs of infection. The radiological findings associated with septic arthritis usually include joint effusion, slight subluxation, and periosteal reaction but do not specifically include Phemister’s triad. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma (Option C): Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically presents with bone pain particularly at night, and swelling, and may have characteristic radiological features like a sunburst pattern or Codman's triangle. However, it is not related to Phemister’s triad. Thus, this option is incorrect.

A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Option D): It is a chronic inflammatory condition in children that can present with joint pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever. The radiological findings are synovial thickening, joint effusion, cartilage loss, and bone erosions. Phemister’s triad is not a feature of JIA. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Person presented to ED with complaints of severe chest pain for 1 hour. CT chest done revealed the presence of Aortic dissection. Patient was taken up for an emergency endovascular surgery without obtaining consent as there were no caregivers present at the time of presentation. Patient succumbed to hypotensive shock during the procedure. The surgeon will not be held liable under which legal provision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) BNS 30

Explanation:

  • Aortic dissection is a surgical emergency without which the patient would die, and does not warrant an obtained consent under emergency circumstances, and so the Surgeon will not be held liable for any unforeseen consequences during/after the procedure under BNS 30.
  • This is known as the Doctrine of Anticipation.

 

BNS 25
  • Act not intended to cause death/grievous hurt done by a person >18 years of age after rightful consent.

BNS 26 (Option A)
  • Act done in good faith for a person’s benefit after obtaining lawful consent.

BNS 27 (Option B)
  • Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person with unsound mind with guardian’s consent

BNS 28 (Option C)
  • Consent given by a person under fear or threat/under misconception of fact/child under 12 years of age/person of unsound mind/under intoxicated state is considered invalid.

BNS 30 (Option D)
  • An act done in good faith for the benefit of a person without their consent is not an offense.
  • This is true if the circumstances make it impossible for the person to give consent.
  • Known as Doctrine of Anticipation.

questions.text: Which of the following components is most accurately matched with its contribution to the total volume of semen?

choices.text: Seminal vesicles contribute 20% of the total volume.
Prostate contributes 60% of the total volume.
Bulbourethral glands contribute the majority of the semen volume.
Seminal vesicles contribute 60% of the total volume.

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Seminal vesicles contribute 60% of the total volume.

 

Explanation:

The seminal vesicles are responsible for producing approximately 60% of the total volume of semen. The fluid from the seminal vesicles is rich in fructose and other substances that provide energy and aid in the motility of sperm.

Sperm Maturation:

  • Spermatogenesis: Begins during adolescence; takes ~74 days.
  • Initial Mobility: Sperm are not fully mobile upon leaving the testes.
  • Maturation: Occurs in the epididymis where sperm gain motility.
  • Motility Mechanism: Involves activation of cation channel proteins (CatSper family) in the sperm tail.
  • Alkaline Sensitivity: CatSpers form an alkaline-sensitive Ca2+ channel, activated as sperm transition from acidic vagina to alkaline cervical mucus.

Sperm Capacitation

  • Location: Occurs in the isthmus of the uterine tubes.
  • Purpose: Prepares sperm for the acrosome reaction and increases motility.

Contents of Semen

  • Composition: Sperm and fluids from seminal vesicles, prostate, Cowper glands, and potentially urethral glands.
  • Volume: 2.5–3.5 mL per ejaculation after several days of abstinence.
  • Sperm Count: About 100 million sperm per mL.
  • Fluid Source:
    • Seminal vesicles: 60% (Option A) (Option D)
    • Prostate: 20% (Option B)
    • Bulbourethral glands: Remaining portion (Option C)

Surface Proteins: Sperm contain proteins like fertilin for egg cell membrane fusion

questions.text: A physician receives a court notice asking him to appear in court to testify in a malpractice case. The notice explicitly orders him to bring relevant patient records to support his testimony. However, he failed to attend court on the scheduled date and did not submit any reason for his absence. Based on the nature of the notice he received and the legal implications of missing the court date, what type of court order did he receive, and what could be the potential legal consequence of his failure to comply?

choices.text: Subpoena ad testificandum, with a fine and/or imprisonment for contempt of court
Subpoena ad testificandum, with a warning but no legal consequences
Subpoena duces tecum, with the possibility of a fine and/or imprisonment for contempt
Subpoena duces tecum, leading to the revocation of his professional license

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subpoena duces tecum, with the possibility of a fine and/or imprisonment for contempt

 

Explanation:

Summons/Subpoena:

  • A subpoena is a legal order mandating a witness to appear before a court on a specific date, time, and location to provide testimony or evidence, under penalty.
  • A subpoena is issued by the court in writing, signed by the presiding officer, and carries the court's official seal (Sec. 63 BNSS).
  • Delivered to the witness by a police officer, court official, or public servant.
  • The witness must sign and return a duplicate copy of the subpoena to acknowledge receipt (Sec. 64 BNSS).

 

Types of Subpoenas

  1. Subpoena duces tecum (Options C and D):
    • The witness is required to bring specific documents or items to the court (e.g., medico-legal reports or postmortem findings).
    • For expert witness.
  2. Subpoena ad testificandum (Options A and B):
    • The witness is required to appear in court to provide oral testimony.
    • For common witnesses.

 

Punishment for Failing to Comply with a Subpoena/Summons:

1. Civil Cases:

  • The witness may be ordered to pay damages for failing to attend court.
  • This involves compensation for the inconvenience caused to the parties involved in the case.

2. Criminal Cases:

  • If a witness fails to appear in court without a justified reason, the following actions can be taken:
  • Under 63 – 71 BNSS, the court may issue a notice to the witness to explain their absence.
  • The court may issue notice under Section 389, BNSS and after hearing the witness, if it finds that the witness neglected to attend the court without a justified reason, may punish him under Section 208 and 209, BNS, and sentence him/her to:
    • A fine (Rs.1000/-), OR
    • Imprisonment (6 months), OR
    • Both fine and imprisonment.
  • Also, the Court may issue bailable or non-bailable warrants to secure the presence of the witness (S.206 to 209, BNS and S.90, BNSS).

 

Prioritization of Summons:

  • Criminal vs. Civil Courts: If a witness is summoned by both criminal and civil courts for the same day, they must attend the criminal court, which takes precedence.
  • Higher vs. Lower Courts: When summoned by two courts of the same jurisdiction (e.g., civil or criminal), the witness must attend the higher court first.
  • Multiple Summons: If the witness receives multiple summonses from the same type of court, they should attend the court that issued the first summons and notify the other.

 

Subpoena ad testificandum, with a fine and/or imprisonment for contempt of court (Option A):

  • Failure to attend court after receiving a Subpoena ad testificandum can result in penalties for contempt of court, including fines or imprisonment.
  • However, it does not relate to document production, which makes it less relevant to the case scenario where documents were requested.

 

Subpoena ad testificandum, with a warning but no legal consequences (Option B):

  • A subpoena ad testificandum does require court attendance for testimony.
  • However, failure to comply with any subpoena typically results in penalties, not merely a warning.


Subpoena duces tecum, leading to the revocation of his professional license (Option D) :

  • Revocation of a professional license is not a standard or direct consequence of failing to comply with a subpoena.
  • It is unlikely unless professional misconduct is also involved.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of urinary obstruction, including difficulty in starting urination, weak urinary stream, and frequent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, he has a history of trauma to the pelvic region. A retrograde urethrogram (RGU) reveals a stricture in the anterior urethra measuring more than 2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

 

Explanation:

 

  • Urethroplasty (Surgical excision and reconstruction) is the gold standard for managing long strictures (greater than 2 cm).
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected stricture segment and reconstructing the urethra using a graft taken from the buccal mucosa.

 

Urethral Stricture

 

Definition

Abnormal narrowing of the urethra, causing partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated.

Causes

Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization.

Infections: STIs like gonorrhea and chlamydia causing urethritis.

Medical Procedures: Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers.

Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus.

Investigations

Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding.

Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU).


Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention.

Management

Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence. (Option A)

Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm).(Option B)

Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures (Option C).

  • Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin.

 

  • Urethral Stenting (Option D) involves placing a stent in the urethra to keep it open.
    • While stenting can relieve obstruction temporarily, it is not a definitive treatment for strictures and may be associated with complications, such as infection and migration of the stent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the clinical triad of sezary syndrome?

choices.text: Atypical mononuclear cells >20% of total lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D
Explanation:
Follicular mucinosis is not a part of the clinical triad of sezary syndrome. It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with boggy plaques and mucinous degeneration of hair follicles.

THE TRIAD CONSISTS OF:

  1. Erythroderma: This refers to diffuse redness affecting more than 80% of the body surface area. The skin appears eczematous and may be associated with variable scaling. Sézary syndrome often presents with rapid-onset itching and erythroderma. It can occur without prior signs of another type of CTCL called mycosis fungoides. (Option A ruled out)
  2. Lymphadenopathy: Generalized enlargement of lymph nodes is a common feature. These swollen lymph nodes are often palpable and can be detected during physical examination. (Option B ruled out)
  3. Atypical Malignant (Sézary Cells): These abnormal T-cells are found in the skin, blood, and lymph nodes, comprising >20% of total lymphocyte count or total sezary count of >1000x109/L. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 34 y/o G3P2 woman at 30 weeks gestation is seen for routine ANC check-up. The fundal height is 36 cm, and an ultrasound shows an AFI of 26 cm. The fetus appears normal and appropriately grown. The patient's glucose tolerance test is normal, and there are no signs of fetal anemia. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Expectant management with close monitoring

Explanation:

An AFI of 26 cm suggests Polyhydramnios.

  • Expectant management with close monitoring is the most appropriate initial management for mild to moderate polyhydramnios without complications
  • It involves:
    • Regular ultrasounds to assess amniotic fluid volume and fetal growth.
    • Non-stress tests to monitor fetal well-being.
    • Maternal education about signs of preterm labour or membrane rupture.
  • Management principles include
    • Relieve symptoms
    • Identify cause
    • Prevent and manage complications

Immediate amnioreduction (Option A) is reserved for:

  • Severe polyhydramnios (typically AFI > 35-40 cm).
  • Significant maternal discomfort or respiratory compromise.
  • Cases where preterm delivery is anticipated.

Indomethacin therapy (Option B) :

  • Used for acute management in preterm pregnancies.
  • It has potential fetal side effects, including premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.
  • It's not the first-line treatment for this case at 30 weeks gestation.

Early delivery via cesarean section (Option D):

This is not appropriate as the initial management because:

  • The patient is only at 30 weeks gestation
  • There are no signs of fetal distress or other complications necessitating immediate delivery.
  • The risks of prematurity outweigh the risks of continuing the pregnancy with monitoring.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with an erythematous plaque with central scarring and an advancing edge on her face. She reports a gradual progression of lesions over several months. Biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following drugs will be started as a part of treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rifampicin

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture shows an erythematous plaque with central scarring and an advancing edge, which suggests a clinical diagnosis of Lupus vulgaris.
  • Rifampicin is an antibiotic that is part of the standard Anti-Tuberculous Therapy (ATT), started in this patient.
  • It is used in combination with other medications, such as Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol, to treat cutaneous tuberculosis, such as lupus vulgaris.

Amphotericin B (Option A):

  • Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication used for serious systemic fungal infections caused by Candida species, Aspergillus species, Cryptococcus neoformans, Histoplasma capsulatum, and other fungi.
  • It is not indicated in the treatment of cutaneous tuberculosis.

Itraconazole (Option B):

  • Itraconazole is an antifungal agent that is commonly used for fungal infections of the skin like dermatophytosis.
  • It would not be effective in treatment against mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Minocycline (Option D) :

  • It is a tetracycline antibiotic with anti-inflammatory properties often used for acne-vulgaris.
  • It is not the treatment of choice for mycobacterial infections.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant presents with developmental delay, coarse facial features, and hepatosplenomegaly. Ophthalmological examination reveals a cherry-red spot on the macula. X-rays show skeletal dysplasia with vertebral abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GM1 gangliosidosis

 

Explanation:

  • The given scenario (bony involvement and cherry red spot) is highly suggestive of GM1 gangliosidosis, a rare inherited lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme beta-galactosidase, resulting in the accumulation of GM1 gangliosides in various tissues, particularly in the central nervous system.
  • Clinical manifestations:
  • Progressive neurodegeneration
  • Developmental delay or regression
  • Seizures
  • Visceromegaly (enlarged liver and spleen)
  • Coarse facial features
  • Cherry-red spot on the macula
  • Skeletal abnormalities
  • Hypotonia

Niemann-Pick disease (Option B) presents with hepatosplenomegaly, lung involvement, and neurological deterioration but typically lacks progressive neuropathy and neuro-regression causing intellectual disability seen in GM1 gangliosidosis.

Tay-Sachs disease (Option C) features a cherry-red spot on the macula and developmental regression but lacks significant visceromegaly or skeletal abnormalities.

Krabbe disease(Option D) is due to the deficiency of galactocerebrosidase enzyme leading to peripheral neuropathy, destruction of oligodendrocytes, developmental delay, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P1, delivered a healthy baby girl via normal vaginal delivery. She is now 2 weeks postpartum and presents for a follow-up visit. On examination, her uterus is not palpable per abdomen. What best describes the normal puerperium duration and uterine involution weight in this patient?

choices.text: Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams
Puerperium is until 8 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 500 grams
Puerperium is until 9 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 1000 grams
Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 100 grams

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams

 

Explanation:

  • Puerperium defines the time following delivery during which pregnancy-induced maternal anatomical and physiological changes return to the nonpregnant state.
  • Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and is considered to last between 4 and 6 weeks.

 

Involution of uterus in puerperium :

Duration

Weight of uterus

Uterus palpable

Immediately after delivery

1000gm (Option C)

Just below the umbilicus

*for 1st 24 hours no change in fundal height. Thereafter, FH decreases @ about 1.25 cm/day.

Fundal height approx. 1 finger breath below the umbilicus on the 2nd postpartum day.

1 week after delivery

500gm (Option B)

Midway between the umbilicus and symphysis pubis

2 weeks after delivery

300gm (Option A)

Not palpable (becomes pelvic organ)

4 weeks after delivery

100gm (Option D)

Involutes completely

questions.text: A 38-year-old premenopausal woman is diagnosed with Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) after a breast biopsy. She opts for chemoprevention as her management strategy. Her doctor discusses various medication options with her. Which of the following statements about chemoprevention for LCIS is correct?

choices.text: Chemoprevention eliminates the risk of developing breast cancer
Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 25% over 5 years
Chemoprevention is only effective for the ipsilateral breast
Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years.

 

Explanation:

Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS)

Management

  • Close observation
  • Chemoprevention
    • Medications: Tamoxifen, Raloxifene, or Arimidex
    • Tamoxifen reduces risk by 56% over 5 years
  • Surgical: Bilateral mastectomy (if surgery chosen prophylactically)

questions.text: A 40 year old woman presents with complaints of persistent nausea, vomiting, and frequent urination over the past few weeks. She has a history of osteomalacia and has been taking supplements for several months without proper medical supervision. Her blood tests reveal elevated serum calcium levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D toxicity aligns with the patient's history of high supplement intake, most probably containing Vitamin D, and her symptoms of nausea, vomiting, frequent urination, and hypercalcemia.

Comparison of Vitamin D Toxicity and Deficiency:

Aspect

Vitamin D Deficiency

Vitamin D Toxicity

Causes

Inadequate dietary intake, insufficient sun exposure, malabsorption syndromes, and certain medical conditions affecting metabolism.

Excessive supplementation.

Dietary intake and sun exposure rarely cause toxicity.

Symptoms

Bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased risk of fractures; in children, it leads to rickets; in adults, it leads to osteomalacia or osteoporosis.

Nausea, vomiting, weakness, frequent urination, and hypercalcemia; can lead to kidney stones and kidney damage.

Serum Levels

Defined as 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) < 30 ng/mL, indicating insufficient levels.

Occurs when 25(OH)D > 150 ng/mL, leading to adverse health effects.

Treatment

Managed with dietary supplementation via food or medications and increased sun exposure.

Requires discontinuation of vitamin D intake, intravenous fluids, and medications, such as corticosteroids or bisphosphonates.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option A) typically presents with elevated serum calcium due to increased parathyroid hormone but is less likely given the context of high supplement intake.

Vitamin D deficiency (Option B) would not cause hypercalcemia; rather, it leads to bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased fracture risk.

Hypercalcemia of malignancy (Option D) can cause elevated serum calcium but does not fit the clinical context of excessive Vitamin D supplementation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman who is sexually active presents to the clinic with complaints of a fish-smelling vaginal discharge that has been ongoing for the past week. On physical examination, there is a thin, white, and creamy vaginal discharge. The physician suspects bacterial vaginosis.

Which of the following criteria would not be required to establish the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis using Amsel's criteria?

choices.text: Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Marked increase in vaginal lactobacilli

Explanation:

Marked increase in vaginal lactobacilli is not a criterion for bacterial vaginosis according to Amsel's criteria. In fact, bacterial vaginosis is typically associated with a decrease in lactobacilli.

The Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis require the presence of at least three out of the following four criteria:

  • Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination (Option A)

  • Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 (Option B)

  • Positive whiff test with KOH (fishy odor) (Option D)

  • Thin, white homogeneous vaginal discharge

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing a fertility evaluation. The transvaginal USG image is shown below. Which phase of the menstrual cycle is she most likely in?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Late proliferative phase

 

Explanation: The late proliferative phase shows the typical trilaminar appearance of the endometrium.

 

Appearances of Endometrium in Various Phases of the Menstrual Cycle

Menstrual and early proliferative phase: (Options A & B ruled out)

  • Thin and brightly echogenic stripe.

Late proliferative phase: (Option C)

  • Trilaminar appearance (outer echogenic basal layer, middle hypoechoic functional layer, and an inner echogenic stripe at the central interface)

Secretory phase: (Option D ruled out)

  • The thickest can be up to 16 mm.
  • Uniformly echogenic.

questions.text: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) El Plantón

 

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts El Planton

 

Torture:

  • Defined as deliberate, systemic, or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

 

Physical torture subtypes

Types of Torture

Description

El Plantón

(Option D)
  • Victim is forced to stand for extended periods in the ‘Army Corps’ poster or body folding or on one leg.
  • Dependent edema and petechiae.

Scaphism

(Option A)
  • An ancient form of execution involving being trapped between two boats and subjected to insects and exposure.


 

Dry Submarine

(Option B)
  • Form of suffocation where the victim's head is wrapped in a plastic bag, causing breathing difficulty.
  • Lung petechiae are seen.


 

Picana/Electric cattle prod

(Option C)
  • An electric torture method that applies electric shocks to the genital region.
  • Reddish brown lesions at points of contact with burning and scarring.

questions.text: A 28 y/o man is admitted to the ED following a motorcycle accident resulting in multiple fractures of the right femur and left humerus. Two days post-injury, he developed sudden onset dyspnea, altered mental status, and a petechial rash around his neck and conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES)

 

Explanation:

Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) is the most likely diagnosis, given the recent trauma, respiratory distress, altered mental status, and petechial rash, which are characteristic signs of FES. Symptoms often develop within 24-72 hours following fat emboli entering circulation.

  • Histopathological image

Fat Embolism Causes
  • Blunt trauma: Accounts for 90% of cases, especially involving extremity fractures.
  • Associated conditions:
    • Acute pancreatitis
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Burns
    • Joint reconstruction surgeries
    • Liposuction
    • Cardiopulmonary bypass
    • Decompression sickness
    • Parenteral lipid infusion
    • Sickle cell crisis
    • Pathologic fractures
  • Increased risk factors (in trauma patients):
    • Age 30 years or younger
    • Closed femur fracture
    • Multiple long-bone fractures

 

Pathophysiology of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES):

  • Mechanism: Not fully understood but involves fat emboli entering circulation, usually after major trauma or surgical procedures (e.g., intramedullary nailing).
  • Pulmonary effects:
    • Fat emboli occlude microvasculature, leading to inflammatory responses and endothelial injury.
    • Pulmonary consequences mimic acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), presenting within 24 hours with symptoms of respiratory failure.
    • Fatty acids released from emboli increase vascular permeability, causing alveolar haemorrhage and oedema.
  • Systemic effects:
    • Involvement of the brain and kidneys, especially in patients with patent foramen ovale
    • Neurologic symptoms include encephalopathy and cerebral oedema due to cerebral vasculature occlusion.

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) (Option A): While the patient shows respiratory failure, the combination of recent trauma, neurologic symptoms, and the petechial rash is more indicative of Fat Embolism Syndrome rather than ARDS alone, which does not typically present with a rash.

 

Pulmonary Embolism (PE) (Option C): Though PE can present with sudden dyspnea and hypoxia, it does not typically cause neurologic symptoms or petechial rash, making FES a more fitting diagnosis in this case.

 

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) (Option D): While DVT is a risk in trauma patients, it usually presents with leg swelling and pain rather than respiratory symptoms and altered mental status, which are not typical manifestations of DVT.

questions.text: Identify the X correctly from the below image of cubital fossa.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cephalic vein

 

Explanation:

The structure marked above is Cephalic vein.

  • Cubital fossa is a triangular space anterior to the elbow.
  • Bordered laterally by the brachioradialis and medially by the pronator teres, with its base formed by the anterior surfaces of the humeral epicondyles.

 

Structure Present in the Cubital Fossa

Contents from Medial to Lateral: (Mnemonic: MBBS)

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery division to ulnar and radial artery
  • Biceps brachii tendon
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents for routine follow-up. He reports increased breathlessness while walking on level ground and has experienced two exacerbations in the past year. According to the 2023 GOLD classification, which group does this patient belong to?

choices.text: Group A: Low risk, low symptoms
Group B: Low risk, high symptoms
Group C: High risk, low symptoms
Group D: High risk, high symptoms

questions.solution:
Group D: High risk, high symptoms is the correct classification for this patient. He has increased breathlessness while walking on level ground, indicating significant symptoms, and his history of two exacerbations in the past year categorises him as high risk.
 

2023 GOLD Classification for COPD:

 

1. New Definition of COPD:

  • Defined as a heterogeneous lung condition with chronic symptoms (dyspnea, cough, sputum production) and persistent airflow obstruction.
  • Diagnosis: Based on FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.7 or LLN (Lower Limit of Normal).

2. Grouping System (A to E):

  • Symptom Severity: Assessed using mMRC dyspnea scale or COPD Assessment Test (CAT).
  • Risk of Exacerbations: Based on the patient's history over the past year.

3. Group Categories:

 

4. Exacerbation Definition Update:

  • Exacerbation: A period of worsened dyspnea, cough, and sputum production (up to 14 days), often linked to infections or environmental factors.

 

Management Strategies by Group:

Group

Treatment

Goals

A

Short-acting bronchodilators (e.g., albuterol) as needed.

Symptom control and improved quality of life.

B

Initiate long-acting bronchodilators (LABA/LAMA).

Focus on symptom relief with low exacerbation risk.

E (formerly C & D)

LABA/LAMA or LABA + ICS (depending on exacerbation history).

Comprehensive management to reduce symptoms and exacerbations.

 

5. Follow-Up and Reassessment:

  • Regular assessment of dyspnea severity and exacerbation frequency.
  • Adjust treatment based on evolving symptoms, exacerbation history, and comorbid conditions.

6. Special Considerations:

  • Manage comorbidities without altering their treatment for COPD.
  • Use inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) only for high-risk patients with frequent exacerbations to minimise unnecessary medication exposure.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the OPD with complaints of excessive thirst, excessive micturition, and increased hunger. He also states that his skin colour has changed in the past six months. He is icteric on examination, and his skin examination reveals findings similar to those in the image below. What is the most likely cause of the change in his skin colour?

choices.text: Excessive melanin production due to adrenal insufficiency
Excessive deposition of melanin and iron in the skin
Excessive deposition of bilirubin in the skin

questions.solution:
Correct option: B) Excessive deposition of iron and melanin in the skin

 

Explanation:

The above patient has features of “Bronze diabetes” and liver dysfunction, which are typically seen in hemochromatosis.

  • In Hemochromatosis, skin colour changes due to the deposition of excessive melanin >> iron in the skin.
  • It is also known as "bronze diabetes" due to skin discolouration and associated pancreatic disease.
  • The disease typically manifests after 20 g of stored iron has accumulated in the body.

Organs affected

Clinical features

Liver

Hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, risk of HCC

Pancreas

Iron induced damage of beta cells - diabetes mellitus

Heart

Cardiomyopathy , arrhythmias, congestive heart failure

Skin

Hyperpigmentation - bronze skin due to melanin and iron deposition

Joints

Arthropathy and joint pain

CNS

Rarely - memory issues, depression and fatigue

Excessive melanin production due to adrenal insufficiency (Option A) is typically seen in Addison’s disease, where adrenal insufficiency leads to increased ACTH derived from Proopiomelanocortin, which also produces MSH and Endorphins, thus leading to melanogenesis, causing darkening of the skin and mucosal membranes

 

 

Insulin resistance (Option C) gives rise to Acanthosis Nigricans, which are hyperpigmented, velvety plaques typically found in body folds such as the neck, axillae, and groin. It is also associated with gastric adenocarcinoma

 


Bilirubin (Option D) deposition leads to jaundice, characterized by a yellowish discoloration of the skin, not the bronze pigmentation seen in hemochromatosis. Jaundice is related to liver dysfunction or hemolysis, not iron overload

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is primarily classified as a water-washed disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trachoma

Explanation:

Water Washed disease also known as Water scarcity disease is associated with inadequate amount of water to maintain personal hygiene. Examples include trachoma, scabies, conjunctivitis, worm infestations.

Type of Disease Definition/Transmission Examples
Water Borne Caused by ingestion of pathogens in contaminated water. Cholera, Typhoid, Diarrhea, Hepatitis A and E, GI infections, Polio.
Water Washed Due to lack of clean water for washing, leading to poor hygiene and sanitation. Infective trachoma, Scabies, Conjunctivitis, Bacillary Amoebic dysentery, Worm infestations.
Water Based Due to the intermediate host in water - Contact with or ingestion of water containing the organisms. Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm disease), Schistosomiasis
Water related/Breeding Diseases that are transmitted by vectors which breed in or near water such as mosquitoes. Malaria, Dengue fever, Japanese Encephalitis, Chikungunya.

questions.text: During a food festival in a small town, 200 people attended a barbecue event. Within 48 hours, 60 attendees developed symptoms of food poisoning. Local health officials want to measure the extent of the outbreak among those who attended the event. What is the term used to describe the proportion of people who developed symptoms out of all the attendees?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Attack rate

Explanation:

The attack rate is the most appropriate measure in this scenario. It represents the proportion of exposed individuals who develop the disease during a specified time period. In this case, we want to measure the extent of food poisoning among those who attended the barbecue event.

To calculate the attack rate:

Number of new cases / Total number of people at risk × 100 = 60 / 200 × 100 = 30%

Secondary attack rate (Option B):

This is a measure of commuicability/transmisibility of a disease. It's typically used for person-to-person transmitted diseases, not for a common source outbreak like food poisoning at an event.

Case fatality rate (Option C) :

This is a measure of severity/virulence of a disease. It is the proportion of individuals who die from a specific disease among those diagnosed with it. It is not applicable here, as we are not provided with death data. We are focused on the extent of the outbreak, not its severity.

Prevalence rate (Option D): This measures the proportion of people with a particular condition at a specific time. It's unsuitable for this acute outbreak scenario, as we're interested in new cases that developed after a specific exposure, not the total number of existing cases in the population.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman with a long-standing history of non-allergic rhinitis presents with persistent nasal obstruction and rhinorrhoea that has not responded to antihistamines and nasal steroid sprays. Which of the following would be the next best step in managing her condition?

choices.text: Increase the dose of topical steroid sprays
Start systemic steroids for a short period and add ipratropium bromide nasal spray

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start systemic steroids for a short period and add ipratropium bromide nasal spray

 

Explanation:

  • Systemic Steroids are appropriate for severe cases when topical treatments have failed.
  • They offer broader anti-inflammatory effects that can help control symptoms more effectively.
  • Ipratropium Bromide Nasal Spray is specifically useful for managing excessive rhinorrhea, and combining it with systemic steroids can provide comprehensive symptom relief.

 

Non-Allergic Rhinitis: Treatment

  • Non-allergic rhinitis presents with symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis (nasal obstruction, rhinorrhoea, sneezing) but without positive allergy tests.
  • Treatment is categorised into medical and surgical options.

 

Medical Treatment:

Treatment Type

Details

Lifestyle Modifications
  • Avoid triggers such as sudden temperature changes, humidity, air blasts, and dust.
  • Practical changes to minimise symptom triggers

Pharmacological Management
  • Antihistamines and Decongestants: Alleviate nasal obstruction, sneezing, and rhinorrhoea.
  • Topical Steroid Sprays: Control Symptoms. Eg. Beclomethasone dipropionate, budesonide, fluticasone
  • Systemic Steroids: Used for severe cases for a short time
  • Ipratropium Bromide Nasal Spray: Effective for Excessive Rhinorrhoea.

Psychological Support

Address emotional factors; consider counselling and tranquillisers.

 

Surgical Treatment:

Surgical Procedure

Details

Examples/Notes

Turbinate Reduction

Reduces nasal obstruction by shrinking turbinate size; also corrects other obstructions.

Submucosal diathermy, resection, cryosurgery, turbinectomy, cauterisation, laser, coblation, radiofrequency.

Vidian Neurectomy

Considered for persistent excessive rhinorrhoea despite medical therapy.

It involves sectioning parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the nose.

 

Increase the dose of topical steroid sprays (Option A):

  • This might help control symptoms, but it has already been tried without sufficient relief.

Vidian Neurectomy (Option C) is a surgical procedure, used for severe non-allergic rhinitis resistant to medical management, that involves cutting parasympathetic nerves to reduce nasal secretions.

  • It is generally considered only after other treatments have failed, so it is not suitable as a first-line option.

Psychological Support and tranquillizers (Option D) can be beneficial for managing emotional distress associated with chronic symptoms, but they do not address the underlying physical symptoms of non-allergic rhinitis.

  • The primary focus should be on managing the physical symptoms before considering psychological interventions.

questions.text: In the graph of a demographic transition model given below, identify the following.

choices.text: A- Death rate, B- Population, C- Birth rate, X- Late expanding
A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Late expanding
A- Death rate, B- Birth rate, C- Population, X- Early expanding
A- Birth rate, B- Death rate, C- Population, X- Early expanding

questions.solution:
Answer: B) A- birth rate, B- death rate, C- population, X- late expanding

Explanation:

According to the demographic transition model, a country goes through 5 phases.

Stages

Birth rate

Death rate

Population

High stationery

High

High

Population is stable

Early expanding

High

Starts declining

Population grows at faster rate.

  • Aka Demographic trap

Late expanding

Starts declining

Keeps declining

Population grows at slower rate (birth > death)

Low stationery

Low

Low

Stable population

Declining

Low

Lower

Population declines (death rate > birth rate)

questions.text: A 50 year old female patient is undergoing a minor surgical procedure on her left forearm using intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) for pain control. During the procedure, the patient suddenly develops seizures and exhibits signs of cardiovascular instability. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step for this patient?

choices.text: Give an additional bolus of lidocaine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Initiate lipid emulsion therapy

 

Explanation:

Intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA): Intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA), also known as a Bier block, is a technique that provides local anesthesia to a specific region of the body, typically an extremity, through intravenous administration of a local anesthetic.

 

Indications
  • Suitable for minor surgical procedures on the upper or lower extremities (hand surgeries, forearm procedures, and foot surgeries).
  • Used when general anesthesia is not necessary and for patients with contraindications to other forms of anesthesia.

Anesthetic Agents
  • Commonly used local anesthetics include lidocaine (most frequent) and prilocaine.

Procedure Steps
  • Tourniquet Application: Apply a tourniquet to the proximal part of the extremity to prevent blood flow and keep the local anesthetic localized.
  • Venous Access: Establish intravenous access in the selected limb.
  • Administration of Anesthetic agent: Inject the local anesthetic into the IV line, typically in a volume of 40-50 mL.

Tourniquet Management

  • The tourniquet should be inflated to a pressure that is approximately 50 mmHg above systolic blood pressure.
  • It is typically safe to keep the tourniquet inflated for 30-60 minutes; prolonged inflation can increase the risk of complications.

Advantages
  • Provides effective analgesia with minimal systemic absorption.
  • Allows for a bloodless surgical field.
  • Quick onset of action and ease of administration.

Disadvantages and Complications
  • Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) Can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation.
  • Tourniquet Pain
  • Nerve Damage

Contraindications
  • Infection at the injection site or over the tourniquet.
  • Severe peripheral vascular disease.
  • Patient refusal or inability to cooperate.

Lipid Emulsion Therapy
  • Used as a treatment for Local anesthesia systemic toxicity, acts by sequestering the local anesthetic from circulation and mitigating toxic effects.
  • Administer a 20% lipid emulsion intravenously if toxicity occurs.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a 2-day history of progressive abdominal distension, constipation, and colicky pain. He has a history of chronic constipation and has been bedridden for the past few months due to a hip fracture. On examination, his abdomen is distended and tympanic, with mild tenderness. Abdominal guarding and rigidity not observed. X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following factors does not predispose to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Short pelvic mesocolon

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical presentation and coffee bean sign in the X-ray abdomen, the most probable diagnosis is sigmoid volvulus
  • Long pelvic mesocolon allows the sigmoid colon to move excessively, predisposing it to twist upon its own mesenteric axis causing sigmoid volvulus.

 

Sigmoid volvulus:

  • It is the twist (rotation) in the axis of the loop of the bowel

 

Predisposing factors:

  • High-residue diet
  • Elderly patients with chronic constipation (Option A ruled out)
  • Chronic psychotropic drug
  • Anticholinergic drugs (Option B ruled out)
  • Mentally-retarded individuals (Option C ruled out)
  • Adhesions; Peridiverticulitis
  • Overloaded redundant pelvic colon
  • Long pelvic mesocolon (Option D)
  • Narrow attachment of sigmoid mesocolon

 

 

Investigations:

  • Plain X-ray
    • omega sign- single grossly distended loop of colon arising out of the pelvis and extending towards the diaphragm.
    • Coffee-bean sign or Bent-inner tube sign

  • Contrast enema:
    • Bird's beak sign (ace of spades appearance)- Upper end of the barium column tapers into the spirally twisted distal sigmoid colon.

questions.text: All of the following changes are true during pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased mean arterial pressure (MAP)


Explanation:

During pregnancy, the mean arterial pressure (MAP) typically decreases or remains relatively stable due to the increased blood volume and decreased systemic vascular resistance. 

 

Change in Pregnancy

Reason

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)

Unchanged

Does not increase during pregnancy; it typically decreases slightly due to decreased systemic vascular resistance despite elevated cardiac output. (Option D)

Systolic Blood Pressure

Decrease

Systemic vascular resistance decreases due to the relaxing effects of progesterone, nitric oxide, prostaglandins, and ANP, leading to lower blood pressure. (Option A)

Stroke Volume

Increase

Blood volume increases during pregnancy, increasing preload and subsequently increasing stroke volume (amount of blood pumped per heart contraction). (Option B)

Pulse Rate

Increase

Heart rate increases by about 15 beats per minute during pregnancy to support the increased cardiac output necessary for the growing fetus. (Option C)

questions.text:
Which of the following features are associated with rickets?


	Craniotabes
	Scorbutic rosary
	Bossing of the skull
	Harrison’s sulcus
	Perifollicular hemorrhage
	Brown's tumour
	Widening of wrists
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 3, 4, 7

 

Explanation:

The features associated with rickets include craniotabes, bossing of the skull, Harrison’s sulcus, and widening of wrists, all of which indicate abnormal bone development and mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency or other underlying issues related to the condition.

 

Clinical Features of Rickets

Nutritional rickets typically occurs in children around 1 year old but can also affect older children with malabsorption syndromes. The following are the clinical features:

  • Craniotabes: This is a sign of rickets seen in young infants, where applying pressure to the soft membranous bones of the skull creates a sensation similar to compressing and releasing a ping pong ball. (Statement 1)
  • Bossing of the Skull: Noticeable swelling of the frontal and parietal bones appears after 6 months of age. (Statement 3)
  • Broadening of Long Bone Ends: This occurs around 6-9 months of age, most prominently at the wrists and knees. (Statement 7)

Widening of wrist joint

  • Delayed Tooth Eruption: Infants may show delays in the appearance of their teeth.
  • Harrison's Sulcus: A horizontal depression develops along the lower part of the chest, corresponding to the diaphragm's insertion. (Statement 4)

  • Pigeon Chest: The sternum becomes prominent.

  • Rachitic Rosary: The junctions between the ribs and cartilage in the anterior chest wall become prominent, resembling a rosary.
  • Muscular Hypotonia: The child may have a protruding abdomen (pot belly) due to marked muscle weakness, along with visceroptosis and lumbar lordosis.
  • Deformities: As the child begins to walk, common presentations of rickets include deformities of the long bones, leading to knock knees or bow legs.

Scorbutic rosary (Statement 2) and Perifollicular haemorrhage (Statement 5) are features associated with vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) and not rickets.

Brown's tumour (Statement 6) is a feature of hyperparathyroidism and is not associated with rickets.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of prior myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with severe palpitations, dizziness, and chest pain. He suddenly becomes pulseless and BP is unrecordable. An ECG shows wide QRS complexes, a regular rhythm, and a ventricular rate of 160 bpm. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Defibrillation

Explanation:

This patient has pulseless/ unstable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) as indicated by the wide QRS complexes, regular rhythm, and associated symptoms (hypotension, chest pain, altered mental status). Hemodynamic instability in VT requires immediate defibrillation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old healthcare worker develops a red, itchy rash on her hands two days after using a new brand of latex gloves. She reports no immediate reaction at the time of exposure, but 48 hours later, she noticed redness, swelling, and itching at the site of contact. She has no known history of allergies or similar reactions in the past. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Type IV

 

Explanation:

Duration of the types of hypersensitivity reactions:

Type I (Immediate): Occurs within 2–30 minutes due to IgE-mediated release of histamine.

 

Type II (Cytotoxic): Can occur within 5–8 hours; mediated by antibody binding to cell antigens, but does not fit the delayed category.

 

Type III (Immune Complex): Symptoms can develop 2–8 hours later but are generally not as delayed as Type IV.

 

Type IV (Delayed): Characterized by delayed hypersensitivity, mediated by T lymphocytes, with symptoms appearing 24 to 72 hours after antigen exposure, as seen in tuberculosis skin tests.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with complaints of persistent fatigue, itching, and mild right upper quadrant abdominal pain. On examination, she has jaundice and hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary biliary cirrhosis
 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms, including fatigue, itching, jaundice, and hepatomegaly, along with elevated alkaline phosphatase and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies, are characteristic of primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC). PBC is an autoimmune disorder leading to the gradual destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts, resulting in cholestasis and liver damage.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (Option A) also presents with cholestasis but is more often associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). PSC involves both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, which would typically be identified in imaging studies. This patient has no history of IBD, and the presentation and test results align more closely with PBC.

Autoimmune hepatitis (Option C) is characterized by elevated serum transaminases rather than an isolated elevation in alkaline phosphatase. It is not commonly associated with anti-mitochondrial antibodies.

While drug-induced liver disease (Option D) can cause cholestasis and elevated liver enzymes, the presence of specific antibodies (AMA), the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the absence of drug history are more indicative of an autoimmune process like PBC.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the “Beck’s cognitive triad”?

choices.text: Perception of the environment as hostile
Expectations of suffering and failure in the future

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Introjection of lost significant object

Explanation:

The introjection of lost objects is a part of the psychodynamic theory of depression, while the cognitive triad is a component of the cognitive theory, involving self-perception, environment, and the future.

Psychosocial Theories of Depression

Life Events and Environmental Stress

  • Stressful life events often precede the first episode of mood disorders.
  • Initial stress may lead to long-lasting biological changes, increasing the risk for future episodes even without further stressors.

 

Psychodynamic Theories

  • Early disturbances in the infant-mother relationship predispose to depression.
  • Depression is linked to real or imagined loss of significant objects.
  • Introjection of lost objects serves as a defense mechanism.
  • Feelings of love and hate toward the lost object result in self-directed anger.

 

Cognitive Theory

  • Depression arises from cognitive distortions known as depressogenic schemata.
  • Cognitive Triad (by Aaron Beck):
    • Worthlessness: Negative self-perception. (Option A)
    • Helplessness: Perception of the environment as hostile and demanding. (Option B)
    • Hopelessness: Expectation of suffering and failure in the future. (Option C)
  • Therapy focuses on modifying these cognitive distortions.

 

Learned Helplessness

  • Developed from studies showing that exposure to uncontrollable stressors (e.g., electric shocks in dogs) leads to passive behavior.
  • Humans may internalize helplessness and lose self-esteem after adverse events.
  • Improvement in depression involves learning a sense of control and mastery over one’s environment.

 

Evolutionary Theory

  • Depression is viewed as an adaptive response to perceived environmental threats.
  • Withdrawal from social situations and decreased activity may serve as protective mechanisms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient who was diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on risperidone 4 months ago now presents with resting tremors, muscular rigidity in the upper limbs and reduced pace in movements. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug of choice for this patient ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Benzhexol

 

Explanation:

  • The above-mentioned clinical vignette is suggestive of drug-induced Parkinsonism, and central anticholinergics like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) are the only drugs of choice for this condition.
  • Patients with Parkinsonism have neurochemical imbalances in the brain, with a reduction in dopamine and an increase in acetylcholine levels, which are together responsible for the symptoms. They include:
    • Procyclidine.
    • Biperiden,
    • Orphenadrine.
    • Promethazine.
    •  Trihexyphenidyl (Benzhexol)

Drugs causing Parkinsonism:

  • MOA: Dopaminergic antagonism.
  • Drugs:
    • Metoclopramide.
    • Haloperidol.
    • Domperidone.
    • Prochlorperazine.
    • Risperidone

questions.text: The clinician performed the following test as shown. Which muscle is being tested here?

choices.text: Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Abductor pollicis brevis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical test done is the Pen test which tests the Abductor pollicis brevis - supplied by Median nerve.
  • Adductor pollicis (Option A): Supplied by ulnar nerve.
    • Book test/Froment sign is done.
  • Flexor carpi radialis (Option B): Supplied by median nerve.
  • Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus (Option D): Supplied by median nerve.
    • Along with Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus does flexion of fingers.
    • Injury to the median nerve will cause a Pointing index sign on Oschner clasp/Benediction test.

Clinical tests for Median nerve:

Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C)
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

 

Treatment of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative management mainly.
  • If not recovered, nerve repair is done by
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months
    • Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient on anti-HIV therapy presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. Laboratory tests reveal hematuria, and a CT scan shows evidence of nephrolithiasis. Which of the following protease inhibitors is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Indinavir

Explanation:

Indinavir (Option A) is a protease inhibitor associated with developing nephrolithiasis (Kidney stones - Radiolucent on X-Ray / may be radiolucent on CT as well) due to its poor solubility in urine.

  • It can lead to the formation of crystals in the urine, causing flank pain, hematuria, and potential obstruction. 
  • Indinavir also causes hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice

Ritonavir, atazanavir, and darunavir (Option B,C&D) are protease inhibitors but are not associated with nephrolithiasis. The table below shows their side effects.

Ritonavir
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances.
  • Hyperlipidemia.
  • Hepatotoxicity.

Atazanavir
  • Indirect hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice).

Darunavir
  • Rash.
  • Liver function abnormalities.
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient with newly diagnosed pulmonary TB begins treatment with ATT. After several weeks of therapy, he complains of difficulty distinguishing colors and experiencing blurred vision. On examination, he exhibits decreased visual acuity and bilateral central scotomas. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ethambutol

 

Explanation:

  • Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that causes retrobulbar neuritis, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness.

Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green color blindness (Yellow vision- Digoxin; Blue vision- Sildenafil)
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

questions.text: A rural clinic generates biomedical waste daily with no nearest biomedical waste treatment facility nearby. What is the most appropriate method for disposing of biomedical waste in this situation?

choices.text: Use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Deep Burial

 

Explanation:

Deep Burial:

  • Indication: No common biomedical waste treatment facility (CBWTF) is available nearby.
  • 2 metres deep.
  • Common practice in PHCs.
  • Biomedical waste should not be disposed of in regular landfills (Option A) due to its hazardous nature and potential for environmental contamination.

 

The use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste (Option C) does not ensure proper treatment of biomedical waste and may lead to contamination of municipal waste streams, posing risks to waste handlers and the public.

questions.text: A state recorded 150 maternal deaths in a year. The number of live births during the same period was 50,000. The total number of women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is 10,00,000. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for this state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 300 per 100,000 live births

 

Explanation:

The question specifically asks for the maternal mortality ratio.

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is the number of maternal deaths during the antenatal period, during delivery, and up to 42 days post delivery per 100,000 live births. It is calculated as follows:

Maternal Mortality Ratio =  ( No. of maternal deaths / No. of Live births )    x   100000

So the answer will be, (150/50000) x 100000 = 300

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with schizophrenia, who has been stable on antipsychotics for years, was recently switched to a higher dose of a first-generation antipsychotic. He then becomes increasingly agitated, develops a high fever, and exhibits severe muscle stiffness, appearing less responsive and confused. The involved receptors and the drug of choice for managing this condition are:
questions.solution:
The scenario is indicative of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS), in which the blockage of D2 receptors leads to extrapyramidal side effects, and the drug of choice for treatment is Dantrolene sodium.

 

Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)

Description

A rare, potentially fatal consequence of neuroleptic administration.

Mechanism

D2 receptor blocking at:

  • Striatum (muscle rigidity)
  • Hypothalamus (hyperthermia)
  • Spinal nerves (autonomic disturbances)
 

Clinical manifestations

Motor and behavioural

Autonomic symptoms
  • Muscular rigidity (most common)
  • Dystonia
  • Akinesia,
  • Mutism
  • Obtundation
  • Agitation
  • Fever (most common)
  • Diaphoresis
  • Raised pulse and blood pressure
  • Sweating
  • Altered consciousness

Associated conditions

Renal failure and myoglobinuria

Laboratory findings
  • Raised levels of creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) (most common)
  • Leukocytosis (raised WBC)
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised plasma myoglobin

Management

  • Stop the drug (causing symptoms)
  • Supportive care (maintain hydration and other vitals)
  • Skeletal muscle relaxants: Dantrolene sodium (drug of choice)
  • Dopamine agonists: Bromocriptine, Amantadine
  • Second-generation antipsychotics (for restarting the treatment for Schizophrenia).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss in his right ear. Audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, and an MRI shows no abnormalities in the cochlear nerve. A defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals is suspected. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Organ of Corti

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss, typically caused by damage to the inner ear or the neural pathways responsible for hearing.
  • Given the defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals, the likely issue lies in the Organ of Corti, where the hair cells transduce sound vibrations into electrical impulses.

  • The Organ of Corti, located on the basilar membrane inside the cochlea, contains the hair cells responsible for the hearing transduction mechanism.
  • When sound waves are transmitted through the ear and reach the inner ear, they cause vibrations of the basilar membrane, which bend stereocilia on the hair cells.
  • Inner hair cells are arranged in a single row, while outer hair cells form three to four rows.
  • Inner hair cells transmit auditory stimuli to the brain, while outer hair cells modulate inner hair cell function to enhance sound sensitivity and clarity.
  • This bending opens ion channels, generating electrical impulses.
  • These impulses are sent through the auditory nerve to the brain, where they are interpreted as sound.

Oval window (Option A) is a membrane-covered opening between the middle and inner ear.

  • It plays a role in the mechanical conduction of sound by transmitting vibrations from the stapes to the fluid in the cochlea but is in converting those vibrations into electrical signals.

Tympanic membrane (Option C) vibrates in response to sound and transmits from the external ear to the ossicles of the middle ear.

  • Damage leads to conductive hearing loss but doesn't affect sound transduction.

Stapes footplate (Option D):

  • This structure amplifies sound waves but involves the conductive hearing process, not sensorineural conversion.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male presents with persistent tearing in his right eye that has worsened over the past year. The physician orders an imaging study to pinpoint the exact location of the blockage and assess the condition of the lacrimal sac. Which investigation is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Dacryocystography

 

Explanation:

  • Dacryocystography (DCG) provides highly detailed anatomical information about the entire lacrimal drainage system.
  • By injecting contrast dye into the lacrimal sac and taking X-rays, DCG can precisely identify the site, extent, and nature of the blockage, making it the investigation of choice when anatomical clarity is required.

Fluorescein Dye Disappearance Test (FDDT) (Option B):

  • 2 drops of the Fluorescein dye are injected into both the conjunctival sacs.
  • It usually disappears in 2 minutes in the normal eye.
  • Longer retention of the dye indicates any obstruction or dysfunction in tear flow.
  • It is mainly used to assess the overall efficiency of tear drainage and does not provide information on the exact location or nature of any obstruction within the lacrimal system.

 

Dacryoscintigraphy (Option C) or lacrimal scintillography is a functional test that evaluates the rate at which tears flow through the lacrimal drainage system by tracking a radioactive tracer.

  • While it is useful for identifying functional delays or blockages, it lacks the anatomical precision needed to determine the exact location or cause of the obstruction.

Lacrimal Syringing (Option D):

  • Normal saline is injected into the lacrimal sac using a syringe.
  • No obstruction: Free passage through the lacrimal passages & the nose
  • Partial obstruction: Saline passes with resistance and pressure.
  • Complete obstruction: No fluid passes.
    • If fluid refluxes through the same punctum: Obstruction in the same or common canaliculus.
    • If fluid refluxes through the opposite punctum: Obstruction in the lower sac or NLD.
  • Although it can identify the degree of blockage & approximate blockage site, it does not offer detailed anatomical information.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with complaints of severe lower abdominal pain that has occurred cyclically every month for the past six months, but she has never had a menstrual period. She reports no other significant symptoms. On physical examination, her secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed (Tanner stage 4). A pelvic examination reveals a bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, along with the type of amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Imperforate Hymen - Cryptomenorrhea

 

Explanation:

  • Imperforate hymen is a common cause of primary amenorrhea with cyclic abdominal pain. A bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus is a classic sign of this condition, indicating the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen.
  • Cryptomenorrhea is a type of primary amenorrhea in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract (such as Imperforate hymen).

 

Primary Amenorrhea is diagnosed when a young girl who has not yet menstruated by:

  • 13 years (in the absence of secondary sexual characters).
  • 15 years (regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characters).

 

Causes of Primary Amenorrhea

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Primary ovarian failure
  • Resistant ovarian syndrome
  • Galactosemia

Developmental defect of genital tract
  • Müllerian agenesis (2nd most common cause)
  • Imperforate hymen (Cryptomenorrhea) 
  • Vaginal agenesis
  • Transverse vaginal septum 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction
  • Kallmann’s syndrome
  • Craniopharyngioma

Abnormal chromosomal pattern
  • Turner’s syndrome (most common cause)
  • Pure gonadal dysgenesis
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Transverse Vaginal Septum - Primary Amenorrhea (Option A): On examination, the hymen would appear normal because the obstruction is higher up in the vaginal canal, not at the introitus.

 

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) - Primary Amenorrhea (Option C): These patients lack a uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina due to normal regression of the Müllerian structures (induced by anti-Müllerian hormone). Therefore, there would be no menstruation and no cyclic abdominal pain. Examination may reveal a short and blind ending vagina.

 

Müllerian Agenesis - Primary Amenorrhea (Option D): Secondary sexual characteristics develop normally. However, there is an absence of the uterus, upper vagina, and fallopian tubes, so the patient would not experience cyclic abdominal pain as there is no menstruation. The examination would reveal a shortened or absent vagina, not a bluish bulging hymen.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with progressive bone marrow failure, short stature, and multiple congenital abnormalities. The child also has distinct skin lesions as shown below. Radiological imaging reveals the following features.

  





Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation

 

Explanation:

  • The above radiological image of absent thumb and radius, along with the history of short stature, progressive bone marrow failure, and café-au-lait macules (hypopigmented skin lesions), is suggestive of Fanconi anemia.
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only curative therapy for Fanconi anemia.

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Features

Absent thumbs, absent radius, microcephaly, renal abnormalities, short stature, café-au-lait spots

Treatment

  • Supportive care - PRBC and platelets transfusion, antibiotics for infection, oral androgens
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (curative) 
  • Horse anti-thymocyte globulin, cyclosporine (contraindicated in children)

Risk of malignancy

AML, myelodysplasia, oral or liver cancer

questions.text: All the following statements about the systemic effects of inhalational agents are correct except:

choices.text: Isoflurane can be safely used in patients with head injury
Halothane is the anesthetic agent of choice in patients with ischaemic heart disease
Almost all inhalational agents cause bronchodilation
Sevoflurane is the anesthetic of choice in bronchial asthma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Halothane is the anesthetic agent of choice in patients with ischaemic heart disease.

Explanation:

Halothane is contraindicated in patients with ischaemic heart disease.

  • Halothane decreases cardiac output, BP, and PR
  • Halothane causes hypotension by direct myocardial depression
  • Halothane causes bradycardia by blunting carotid body receptor response
  • Halothane is a common inhalational agent used in the respiratory system (due to maximum bronchodilation) while Isoflurane is the common inhalational agent used in CNS and CVS

Central Nervous System:

  • Inhalational agents are CNS depressant
  • They reduce cerebral metabolic rate
  • Commonly used inhalational agent is isoflurane
  • They increase the cerebral blood flow thereby increasing the ICP, so they are avoided in head injury and neurosurgery (maximum with halothane)
  • Isoflurane is an inhalational agent of choice in head injury as it decreases the ICP (Option A)
  • Most epileptogenic agent: Enflurane (increases ICP and also causes epilepsy)

Respiratory system

  • Almost all inhalational agents cause bronchodilation (Option C)
  • Reduces the Respiratory rate
  • Causes decreased mucociliary function (except ether)
  • Maximum bronchodilation is seen with halothane, therefore 2nd best inhalational agent for bronchial asthma is halothane.
  • Best inhalational agent for bronchial asthma: Sevoflurane (Option D)

Cardiovascular system

  • Reduces heart rate, BP, and systemic vascular resistance
  • Halothane increases the sensitivity of the myocardium toward catecholamines
  • Halothane, isoflurane, enflurane - prolong QT interval

Gastrointestinal system:

  • Reduces the liver blood flow
  • Halothane hepatitis: maximally metabolized produces trifluoroacetic acid as an end product that reacts with liver cells (immunologically) causing acute fulminant hepatic necrosis.

Uterus:

  • All agents are good uterine relaxants so there is a high chance of PPH

questions.text:
Match the following radiological findings with their associated condition.


	
		
			
			Radiological finding
			
			
			Condition
			
		
		
			
			1.
			
			
			 a) Paget's disease
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			b) Vertebral hemangioma
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c) Osteopetrosis
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			d) Ankylosing spondylitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Vertebral appearances

Seen in

Radiological image

Bone within bone appearance

Osteopetrosis

(Marble bone disease)

  • Bone within bone appearance

Intervertebral Disc Calcification
  • Ochronosis alkaptonuria
  • Ankylosing spondylitis

Polka Dot Appearance and Corduroy/Jail BarAppearance:

Vertebral hemangioma

Ivory Vertebrae
  • Paget's disease
  • Lymphoma
  • Osteoblastic metastasis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has been a heavy smoker for the past 40 years and presents with complaints of progressive shortness of breath, especially with exertion, and a chronic cough with occasional scanty sputum production. Physical examination reveals a barrel-shaped chest, decreased breathing sounds, and a prolonged expiratory phase. Based on the clinical presentation and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Emphysema

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of heavy smoking, chronic cough with occasional scanty sputum production, progressive shortness of breath, especially with exertion and physical examination showing barrel-shaped chest, decreased breath sounds, and a prolonged expiratory phase is highly suggestive of COPD with emphysema.
  • Clinically significant emphysema is largely confined to smokers and patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Clinical features:

  • The classical presentation of emphysema involves a barrel-shaped chest and dyspnea, with obviously prolonged expiration, sitting forward in a hunched-over position, and breathing through pursed lips.
  • Cough is often slight, overdistention of the lungs is severe, diffusion capacity is low, and blood gas values are relatively normal at rest.
  • Weight loss is common and can be so severe as to suggest an occult cancer.


Chronic bronchitis (Option A) presents insidiously with slowly increasing dyspnea on exertion and chronic cough with sputum production, slight at first but increasing over time.

  • The most important diagnostic test is spirometry, which typically shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7.
  • The main clinically distinguishing factor between emphysema and chronic bronchitis is that chronic bronchitis is characterized by a persistent, mucus-producing cough. In contrast, the primary symptom of emphysema is shortness of breath.

 

Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C) is characterized by progressive scarring of the lungs, leading to decreased lung compliance and restrictive lung disease.

  • The chest X-ray findings of hyperinflated, hyperlucent lungs are not consistent with pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Asthma (Option D) is characterized by reversible airflow obstruction, wheezing, and chest tightness, but the patient's history of heavy smoking and clinical presentation is not typical of asthma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 26 weeks of gestation visits the antenatal clinic for her routine check-up. Her haemoglobin (Hb) level is found to be 8.5 g/dl.
