It was 10 g/dl at her booking visit. She has been compliant with her IFA supplementation. What should be the next step in managing this patient’s anaemia?

choices.text: Continue with oral Iron and Folic Acid tablets and recheck Hb after one month.
Switch to parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose).
Refer to the higher center for further investigation and management.
Increase the dose of oral Iron and Folic Acid tablets and recheck Hb after two weeks.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Refer to the higher centre for further investigation and management.

Explanation:

Despite oral Iron and Folic Acid adherence, the patient’s Hb remains at 8.5 g/dl, indicating persistent anaemia, management protocol, referral to higher care for further investigation and possible parenteral iron therapy is recommended after minimal improvement over two months.

 

Anaemia management protocol for pregnant women

Target Group

Pregnant women registered for antenatal care

Screening and Periodicity

By health service provider at every ANC checkup

Degree

Of anaemia

First Level of Treatment

Follow-up

If No Improvement

Mild anaemia (Hb 10–10.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance.
  • Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose
  • Refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) if Hb <1 g/dl increase after one month of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Moderate anaemia (Hb 7–9.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases.
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance. Monthly Hb estimation. Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose.
  • Refer to FRU/DH if Hb <1 g/dl increase after two months of treatment Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Severe anaemia (Hb 5.0–6.9 g/dl)
  • Managed by medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH.
  • Treatment with IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxymaltose.
  • Immediate hospitalization in the third trimester is recommended at higher facility.
  • Monthly or as prescribed by the medical officer
  • Follow treatment protocol as prescribed by the medical officer

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents for a preoperative evaluation before a scheduled elective surgery. During the airway assessment, the base of the uvula is visible, with the soft palate and hard palate clearly seen. Based on this finding, which Mallampati classification is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Class III

Explanation

  • The Mallampati classification is used to assess the ease of intubation based on the visibility of oropharyngeal structures when the patient opens their mouth and protrudes their tongue.

  • In this case, the base of the uvula is visible along with the soft and hard palate, which fits Class III.

Mallampati Classification Summary

Class Visible Structures
Class I (Options A & D) Hard palate, soft palate, , tonsillar pillars, uvula body, base and tip visible
Class II (Option D) Hard palate, soft palate, uvula body & base and tonsillar pillars visible (Uvula tip not visible)
Class III (Option C) Only hard palate, soft palate and base of uvula visible (Uvula body and tip not visible)
Class IV Only hard palate visible

questions.text: A 15 year old patient presents with anemia with splenomegaly. P. Smear is shown below. Comment on the Peripheral smear shown below
questions.solution:
Correct answer id d: Pyropokilocytosis

The image shows marked poikilocytosis with microspherocytes, schistocytes, and elliptocytes. Looks similar to smear in severe burns.

Pyropoikilocytosis is a rare form of hereditary elliptocytosis characterized by extreme red blood cell shape abnormalities and marked thermal sensitivity of the RBC membrane. It is autosomal recessive and occurs when a person inherits two abnormal spectrin alleles.

questions.text: Following CT image is kept as a spotter in your final year exam viva. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Marked cell located between floor of orbit and superior boundary of maxillary sinus is known as Haller cell - an example of anterior ethmoidal air cell.

 

Ethmoidal air cells:

Anterior Air cells:

Agger Nasi
  • Anterior most air cell of Ethmoid sinus
  • Site: Within the Lacrimal bone in the medial side of the Orbit
  • Relation: Anterolateral and inferior to the frontal recess

Haller cell
  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cell
  • Site: Present between floor of orbit and upper boundary of maxillary sinus

Bulla ethmoidalis
  • Most consistent and largest ethmoid air cell
  • Located just posterior to the Agger nasi

 

Posterior Air cells:

Onodi cell
  • Also known as spheno-ethmoidal air cell
  • Close proximity to Optic nerve and Internal carotid artery
  • Better appreciable on CT- axial view

 

Concha bullosa (Option A):

  • Pneumatization of middle turbinate
  • Most common deformity seen in nose, non-pathological
  • CT:


 

Pneumatized superior turbinate (Option C):

  • Occasionally the superior turbinate can undergo pneumatization
  • CT:

questions.text: “The risk of contracting a disease increases if profit is valued more than health”. This statement represents which of the following theories in sociology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Marxist theory.

 

Explanation:

Theories in sociology

Marxist theory
  • Putting profit as a priority instead of health
  • Eg: Alcohol and tobacco consumption is not completely banned as it leads to loss of revenue

Parsonian theory
  • Social factors like poverty, migration and industrialisation playing a role in disease etiology
  • Eg, TB due to overcrowding from poverty

Feminist theory
  • Females are enforced by men to do particular roles

Foucauldian theory
  • By segregating the population into groups, they can be controlled easily

Mckeown’s theory of TB
  • Changes in socio-environmental conditions lead to a reduction in TB

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns about poor growth. The child appears emaciated, with visible rib bones and a sunken appearance of face. On examination, there is minimal subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting. The mother reports that the infant has been exclusively breastfed, but she herself has been malnourished due to economic constraints. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Marasmus

 

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis for the 14-month-old infant who appears emaciated with minimal subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting, especially in the context of being exclusively breastfed by a malnourished mother, is marasmus.

Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterised by energy deficiency. It typically presents with significant weight loss, visible rib bones, a sunken facial appearance, and muscle wasting.

Protein-energy malnutrition:

  • Kwashiorkor.
  • Marasmus.

 

Characteristic

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

Cause

Low protein/energy ratio in diet

Inadequate intake of both protein and energy

Affected age group

1 to 4 years

< 1 year

Severity 

Severe 

Less severe 

Physical appearance

Lethargic, moon face due to edema, flaky paint dermatosis & flag sign

Alert & thin, loose wrinkled  skin, baggy pants appearance & muscle wasting

Feeding behaviour

Children are usually voracious feeders. 

Often poor appetite or anorexia 

Oedema 

Present 

Minimal or no oedema

Subcutaneous fat

-

Minimal or absent

Muscle wasting

Present 

Present 

Serum albumin levels

Hypoalbuminemia (low albumin levels)

Non-normal serum albumin levels

Liver involvement

Enlargement

-

Skin and hair changes

Depigmentation

-

Other features

Steatosis (fatty liver)

-

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the Delphi technique?

choices.text: A method of data collection where participants discuss and agree on a topic in person.
A qualitative research method that involves direct observation of participants in their natural environment.
A structured communication technique used in health research that relies on a panel of experts answering questionnaires in multiple rounds to achieve consensus.
A statistical analysis method used to interpret large datasets through the use of complex algorithms.

questions.solution:
Correct option: C) A structured communication technique used in health research that relies on a panel of experts answering questionnaires in multiple rounds to achieve consensus.

Explanation:

Delphi method is a structured communication method that depends on a panel of experts.

  • It involves gathering opinions from the panel of experts on a specific issue, summarizing their collective feedback, and repeating this process for several rounds.
  • After each round, the experts share their feedback and the reasoning behind their judgements anonymously. This feedback encourages experts to reconsider and potentially revise their earlier opinions based on the responses of other panel members.
  • Through this process, the range of responses tends to narrow, and the group will reach a consensus.

The Delphi method does not involve participants discussing the issues (Option A) or natural observation (Option B) or statistical analysis (Option D).

questions.text: An elderly patient with a history of an intracapsular neck of femur fracture presents with hip pain radiating to the groin and thigh, worsening with activity but improving with rest. Examination reveals restricted range of motion and tenderness in the hip. Which of the following arteries is not typically involved in the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inferior gluteal artery

 

Explanation:

The symptoms and examination findings, including hip pain radiating to the groin and thigh, worsened by activity and restricted motion, indicate avascular necrosis of the femoral head, commonly following an intracapsular neck of femur fracture.

The inferior gluteal artery primarily supplies the gluteal region and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the femoral head. Therefore, it is not typically involved in AVN associated with neck of femur fractures.

 

Blood supply to the femoral head and neck

 

Blood Supply Source

Description

Retinacular Vessels
  • Major supply, derived from the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries (branches of the deep femoral artery).
  • Forms an extensive network along the femoral neck.

Intraosseous Cervical Vessels
  • Secondary source, providing additional vascular support through small penetrating vessels along the femoral neck.

Artery of Ligamentum Teres
  • Tertiary source, also called the foveolar artery.
  • Supplies the femoral head via the ligamentum teres.
  • Important in younger patients or in cases of trauma.

Obturator Artery
  • Provides minor support through its acetabular branch.
  • Primarily supplies the medial thigh muscles but contributes to anastomoses around the hip joint.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a slow-growing painless mass in the left submandibular gland region. Imaging studies reveal a solid lesion with cystic components. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) shows a mixture of mucin-producing, epidermoid, and intermediate cells. A histopathology image is given below. Which of the following features is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most commonly found in the sublingual salivary glands.
Most are associated with a (11;19) translocation.
Histologically characterized by the presence of spindle cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Most are associated with a (11;19) translocation.

Explanation:

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC):

  • It is the most common malignant tumour of salivary glands, often found in parotid and submandibular glands. (Option A)
  • It does not have a capsule (Option C)
  • It is associated with the (11;19) chromosomal translocation, creating CRTC1-MAML2 fusion protein.
  • Histologically, it exhibits squamous and mucous cell features. (Option D)
  • There are 3 types of cells in Mucoepidermoid carcinoma:
    • Mucus-producing cells
    • Epidermoid or Squamoid cells
    • Intermediate cells.
  • Grading: 
    • Low grade MEC: If mucus component is predominant.
    • High grade MEC: If epidermoid or squamoid component is predominant.

Image: Low-power view showing sheets and micro cysts containing cells of varying morphologies in Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a condition in which, upon examination, the left eye fails to adduct during right gaze. The patient reports diplopia, which is more noticeable when looking to the right. Which extraocular muscle is most likely overacting in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right Lateral Rectus

 

Explanation:

Given that the left eye fails to adduct and diplopia is more noticeable during right gaze, it suggests that the left medial rectus is not functioning properly.

  • Hering’s Law of Equal Innervation would mean that the right lateral rectus (yoke muscle) should be balanced with the left medial rectus (vs Sherrington’s law:
    • This law about reciprocal innervation states that increased innervation and contraction of a muscle is automatically associated with reciprocal decrease in innervation and contraction of its antagonist).
  • If the left medial rectus is weak or underacting, the corresponding yoke muscle, the right lateral rectus, might be compensating and thus appearing to overact.
  • Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles, one in each eye, that work together to ensure coordinated eye movements in the same direction.
  • These muscles function according to Hering's Law of Equal Innervation, which ensures that corresponding muscles in both eyes receive equal neural impulses for synchronised movement.
  • The yoke muscle pairs facilitate various eye movements:

  1. Horizontal Gaze (Left or Right):
    • Leftward Gaze (Levoversion):
      • Left Lateral Rectus (abducts the left eye)
      • Right Medial Rectus (adducts the right eye)
    • Rightward Gaze (Dextroversion):
      • Right Lateral Rectus (abducts the right eye)
      • Left Medial Rectus (adducts the left eye)
  2. Vertical Gaze (Up or Down):
    • Upward Gaze (Elevation):
      • Right and Left Superior Rectus (elevate the eyes)
      • Right and Left Inferior Oblique (assist in elevation)
    • Downward Gaze (Depression):
      • Right and Left Inferior Rectus (depress the eyes)
      • Right and Left Superior Oblique (assist in depression)
  3. Inward Gaze (Convergence):
    • Both Medial Rectus muscles contract to bring the eyes inward (toward the nose) during near-vision tasks, such as reading.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with redness, pain, and decreased vision in his right eye. He reports a history of trauma to the eye with a plant material three days ago. O/E, there is a corneal ulcer with feathery edges and satellite lesions. Hypopyon is also noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical Natamycin

 

Explanation:

  • The history of trauma with plant material, along with the presence of a corneal ulcer with feathery edges and satellite lesions, is highly suggestive of fungal keratitis.
  • Natamycin is the first-line treatment for fungal keratitis, especially caused by filamentous fungi like Fusarium and Aspergillus.
  • It is effective in treating the type of fungal infection that is suggested by the clinical presentation in this patient.

 

Topical Moxifloxacin (Option A):

  • Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic effective against bacterial infections, not fungal infections.
  • Given the history of trauma with plant material and the appearance of a corneal ulcer with feathery edges and satellite lesions, the most likely diagnosis is fungal keratitis.
  • Therefore, moxifloxacin would not be appropriate.

Oral Acyclovir (Option C):

  • Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used primarily for herpes simplex virus infections.
  • It would not be effective for a fungal corneal ulcer, making it an inappropriate choice in this scenario.

Intravitreal Amphotericin B (Option D):

  • Intravitreal Amphotericin B is used in cases of fungal endophthalmitis, not as an initial treatment for keratitis.
  • Although hypopyon suggests severe infection, the primary treatment should still be topical antifungal agents unless there is confirmed or high suspicion of endophthalmitis requiring intravitreal therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain, high fever, and an elevated heart rate. She appears pale and diaphoretic on examination, with hypotension and a leukocytosis noted on laboratory tests. Imaging reveals a pelvic abscess. The surgeon suspects that pus has spread from an upper abdominal source. Which of the following sequences represents the correct flow of pus between important peritoneal spaces, leading to a pelvic abscess?

choices.text: Rectouterine pouch → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Lesser sac → Pelvic abscess
Lesser sac → Foramen of Winslow → Greater sac → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Rectouterine pouch → Pelvic abscess
Greater sac → Foramen of Winslow → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Lesser sac → Pelvic abscess
Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Lesser sac → Foramen of Winslow → Pelvic abscess

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lesser sac → Foramen of Winslow → Greater sac → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Rectouterine pouch → Pelvic abscess

 

Explanation:

Pus moves from the lesser sac through the foramen of Winslow into the greater sac, enters the hepatorenal pouch of Morrison, continues through the paracolic gutter, then reaches the rectouterine pouch of Douglas, where a pelvic abscess may form.

Peritoneal Spaces:

  • Greater Sac:
    • Largest compartment of the peritoneal cavity, spanning the entire abdomen.
  • Lesser Sac:
    • Smaller compartment, located behind the stomach, liver, and lesser omentum, as a diverticulum from the greater sac.
    • Both the sacs can be connected through the foramen of Winslow.
  • Paracolic Gutters:
    • Right Paracolic Gutter:
      • Located lateral to the ascending colon, continuous with the hepatorenal pouch (Morrison’s pouch) above and pelvic cavity below.
      • Infections may spread from the appendix or hepatorenal pouch.
    • Left Paracolic Gutter:
      • Located lateral to the descending colon, limited by the phrenicocolic ligament above, and continuous with the pelvic cavity below.
      • Infections may spread upward from the pelvis.
  • Subphrenic Spaces:
    • Six spaces near the liver, important for surgeons due to frequent pus collection (subphrenic abscesses).
    • Right side:
      • Right posterior intraperitoneal compartment (Hepatorenal pouch or Morrison's pouch).
      • Right anterior intraperitoneal compartment.
      • Right extraperitoneal compartment.
    • Left side:
      • Left posterior intraperitoneal compartment.
      • Left anterior intraperitoneal compartment.
      • Left extraperitoneal compartment.
  • Hepatorenal Pouch (Morison’s Pouch):
    • Located between the liver and right kidney, communicates with the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen.
    • Most dependent part in the supine position, often collecting pus after upper abdominal surgery (e.g., cholecystectomy).
    • Communicates with the rectouterine pouch via the right paracolic gutter, serving as a route for infection from the abdomen to the pelvis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active female presents with dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and mild cervical discharge on per speculum examination.. She denies fever or abdominal pain. A urinalysis reveals pyuria, but no bacteria are seen on Gram staining of the discharge. Which of the following agents is the first-line drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and absence of bacteria on Gram stain suggest Chlamydia trachomatis as the likely cause of non-gonococcal cervicitis. The first-line treatment is a single dose of Azithromycin (1g orally).
  • The diagnosis of NGU/NGC requires the exclusion of gonorrheal infection. This can be achieved with a gram stain that lacks gram-negative diplococci or by any negative gonorrhea test (culture, nucleic acid testing, among others).

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D-K are the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis. In females, it can cause various manifestations such as:

  • Mucopurulent cervicitis (most common).
  • It may progress to endometritis, salpingitis (fallopian tube), pelvic inflammatory disease, and finally pelvic peritonitis.
  • Perihepatitis (Fitz–Hugh–Curtis syndrome).

First-line management involves a single oral dose of azithromycin 1g stat. It is preferred due to its greater effectiveness and lower cost.

The table below shows the management of uncomplicated chlamydial infections:

Non-pregnant

First line: Azithromycin 1g single dose

Second line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 7 days

Third line: Ofloxacin 200-300mg BD x 7 days

Pregnancy

First line: Azithromycin 1g oral single dose

Second line: Amoxicillin 500mg TDS x 7 days

 

Ceftriaxone (Option B) is used for the treatment of gonococcal infections.

Fluconazole (Option C) is used for the treatment of vaginal candidiasis.

Doxycycline (Option D) is also highly effective for treating uncomplicated chlamydial infections. It is used when azithromycin is not available or there is a history of allergies. The recommended dose is 100 mg BD x 7 days.

questions.text:
A clinical trial of 4 new drugs was conducted, and the following graph was obtained. Based on this graph, which of the following statements is/are correct?



a) Drug A has the highest efficacy as well as the highest potency.

b) Drug A has the highest efficacy but the lowest potency.

c) Drug D has the highest efficacy as well as the highest potency.

d) Drug B is more potent than drug C.

choices.text: Statements a and d are correct
Statements b and d are correct
None of the statements are correct

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Statements a and d are correct

 

Explanation:

Drug A has the highest efficacy with the highest potency.

Drug B is more potent than drug C.

  • Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce, represented by the Vmax /y-axis value. The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.
  • Potency is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect. The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.
  • Both are independent of each other; efficacious drugs can have high or low potency and vice versa.
  • The first graph helps us estimate the efficacy of the drugs (the higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy). Thus, Drug A > B >C >D.
  • The second graph helps us estimate the drugs' potency (The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency). The left shift of the graph indicates an increase in potency. Thus Drug D > B > C > A.

questions.text: Functional imaging of choice for diagnosis of ZES is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Ga-68 DOTATE PET-CT

  • Ga-68 DOTATE PET-CT is the imaging modality of choice now for Neuroendocrine tumors and pheochromocytoma with sensitivity > 90%.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after ingesting the seeds given in the image. He has severe abdominal pain, bloody vomiting, dizziness, and a rapid, weak pulse. What is the mechanism of action of the toxic compound present in the seeds?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium ion channels, causing cell death.
Blocks RNA polymerase, preventing protein synthesis
Binds to ribosomal RNA, inhibiting protein synthesis.
Disrupts mitochondrial function, leading to energy failure.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Blocks RNA polymerase, preventing protein synthesis.

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and given image suggest ingestion of Ricinus seeds.
  • Ricin, a highly toxic protein derived from the seeds of Ricinus communis, blocks RNA Polymerase and inhibits protein synthesis.

 

Ricinus Communis (Castor):

  • Seeds are smooth, flattened-oval, and mottled with light and dark brown markings.
    • They have a bright, polished finish.
  • Toxicity: The entire plant is toxic due to the water-soluble glycoprotein toxalbumin Ricin, a potent allergen with the highest concentration found in the seeds.
    • The seeds are not toxic if intact but it is toxic if crushed or chewed.
  • Mechanism of action: Ricin inhibits protein synthesis by blocking RNA polymerase.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms may appear within 10 hours after ingestion.
    • Gastrointestinal: Burning throat pain, abdominal cramps, nausea, thirst, vomiting, and often bloody diarrhea.
    • Central Nervous System: Vertigo, drowsiness, delirium, convulsions, and coma.
    • Other Symptoms include uremia, jaundice, rapid weak pulse, cold, clammy skin, and dehydration.
    • In some cases, consciousness may be retained until death.
  • Fatal Dose: 1–10 µg/kg body weight (inhalation or injection); approximately 2 mg/kg (10–20 seeds) through ingestion.
  • Fatal Period: 3–5 days.
  • Ingestion of castor oil during pregnancy has been associated with teratogenic effects, including growth retardation, craniofacial dysmorphia, limb deformities, vertebral segmentation defects, and seizures in some cases.
  • Treatment:
    • No specific antidotes exist for toxalbumen exposures.
    • Decontamination: Stomach wash, activated charcoal, and catharsis.
    • Supportive Care: IV fluids and monitoring for hypoglycemia and complications of hypovolemia.
    • Urine alkalinisation may help prevent the crystallisation of haemoglobin in severe cases

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with hypertension presents with profuse nasal bleeding from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, unresponsive to pinching and anterior packing. Nasal endoscopy shows bleeding behind the middle turbinate. What is the likely source of bleeding and appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sphenopalatine artery, Endoscopic intervention

 

Explanation:

  • The sphenopalatine artery is the most common source of posterior epistaxis in hypertensive patients.
  • It supplies the lateral nasal wall and posterior nasal cavity.
  • Endoscopic ligation or cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery is the preferred treatment for severe, uncontrolled posterior nasal bleeding.

 

Classification of Epistaxis:

Feature

Anterior Epistaxis

Posterior Epistaxis

Definition

Bleeding from the front of the nose

Bleeding that flows backwards into the throat

Source of bleeding

Kiesselbach's plexus
(Anterior ethmoidal artery, Septal branch of Superior labial artery, Septal branch of Sphenopalatine artery, Greater palatine artery)
  • Sphenopalatine artery (Most common)
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

Site

Little's area (anteroinferior nasal septum)

Posterior or superior parts of the nasal cavity (e.g.Woodruff's plexus)

Age Group

Mostly in children and young adults

More common in adults over 40 years old

Usual Cause

Trauma (e.g., nose picking, injury)

Spontaneous, often associated with hypertension and arteriosclerosis

Management

Local pressure and conservative measures

Postnasal pack, more aggressive treatment often required

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with signs of early virilization and ambiguous genitalia. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ACTH and 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
21β-hydroxylase deficiency leads to reduced cortisol and aldosterone production, causing elevated ACTH and increased production of androgens, resulting in virilization and ambiguous genitalia.

 

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

  • Definition: Group of genetic disorders affecting adrenal glands, causing enzyme deficiencies in steroid biosynthesis.
  • Effects: Disruption in cortisol and aldosterone production, leading to various symptoms.
  • Prevalence: Most common deficiency is 21β-hydroxylase deficiency (90%+ cases).

21β-Hydroxylase Deficiency

  • Impact: Reduced cortisol and aldosterone production.
  • Consequence: Increased ACTH secretion. (Option B)
  • Result: Increased precursor steroids converted to androgens → Virilization.

Other Enzyme Deficiencies in CAH

Enzyme Deficiency

Description

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase deficiency

Fatal in utero, prevents placental progesterone synthesis.

Death before birth.

Steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein deficiency

Known as congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia. Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency

Increases DHEA secretion (weak androgen).

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males. (Option C)

17α-Hydroxylase deficiency

Caused by mutated CYP17 gene. Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia due to high 11-deoxycorticosterone. (Option D- not early virilization)

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

Increased 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone secretion.

Virilization, hypertension due to salt and water retention. (Option A)

Treatment

  • Glucocorticoid treatment: Recommended for all virilizing forms of CAH.
    • Purpose: Addresses glucocorticoid deficit.
    • Effect: Inhibits ACTH secretion, reducing androgen and steroid production.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with persistent eye discomfort, redness, and watering. On examination, the left eye is diffusely tender, sclera appears uniformly reddened and swollen without localized thinning areas. There are no systemic signs of vasculitis or autoimmune disease on further investigation. Which type of anterior scleritis is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation of persistent eye discomfort, watering, diffuse redness, and tenderness without localized necrosis or thinning is characteristic of non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis.

Clinical classification:

  • Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis: Pain, redness, watering, discharge, and bluish or brownish discoloration.
    • Diffuse
    • Nodular (Option C): One or more dark red or bluish nodules, which later become purple and semitransparent like porcelain.
  • Necrotizing anterior scleritis
    • With inflammation
    • Without inflammation

Necrotizing anterior scleritis with inflammation​​​​​​​: (Option A)

  • Severe form of scleritis
  • Red, painful eye, and progressive worsening of symptoms

Scleromalacia perforans (Option D): Necrotizing, painless form seen in rheumatoid arthritis patients with scleral thinning

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy has been brought to the emergency department with severe vomiting for the past 2 days. He appears dehydrated and lethargic.

Laboratory studies reveal:

pH: 7.52

pCO2: 38 mmHg

HCO3-: 32 mEq/L

Na+: 138 mEq/L
Cl-: 90 mEq/L
Urinary Chloride: 10 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Initiate normal saline infusion

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with metabolic alkalosis (pH > 7.45, increased HCO3-) likely due to severe vomiting.
  • Also, the low urinary chloride (< 15 mEq/L) indicates a chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis.
  • The most appropriate treatment is to initiate normal saline infusion.

Acid-Base Disorder

Primary Cause

Initial Treatment

Additional Considerations

Metabolic Acidosis

Excess HCO3- loss or H+ retention
  • Treat underlying cause
  • Fluid resuscitation (e.g., normal saline)
  • Start sodium bicarbonate (Option A)
  • Sodium bicarbonate rarely used, only if pH < 7.1 or life-threatening
  • Address electrolyte imbalances after initial resuscitation

Respiratory Acidosis

CO2 retention due to respiratory compromise
  • Assisted ventilation (NIV/IMV)
  • Treat underlying cause

For every 10 mmHg increase in pCO2, there is 4 mEq/L rise in HCO3- (metabolic compensation)

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Responsive)
  • HCl loss (e.g., vomiting)
  • Urinary chloride < 15 mEq/L
  • Volume repletion with normal saline
  • Most common type
  • Responds to fluid and chloride replacement

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Resistant)
  • Various endocrine disorders
  • Urinary chloride > 20 mEq/L
  • Treat underlying cause
  • May require specific treatments based on etiology (e.g., spironolactone for Liddle syndrome)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Does not respond to volume repletion alone
  • Requires targeted therapy based on specific diagnosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

CO2 washout due to hyperventilation
  • Treat underlying cause (e.g., fever, sepsis, asthma)
  • Adjust ventilator settings if over ventilated
  • Monitor for hypocalcemia (may cause tetany, seizures)
  • Metabolic compensation occurs over days

Provide oxygen therapy (Option B):

  • Oxygen therapy is not indicated in the treatment of metabolic alkalosis.
  • The patient's primary issue is related to fluid and electrolyte imbalances due to vomiting, not a respiratory or oxygenation problem.

Start acetazolamide (Option D):

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that can be used to correct metabolic alkalosis by increasing renal bicarbonate excretion.
  • However, the immediate need is to address the underlying cause of the alkalosis, which in this case is due to chloride loss from vomiting.
  • Normal saline is usually the initial treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Colposuspension surgery

Explanation:

In this scenario, all the conservative and less invasive measures have failed. Hence, the next best step in management is colposuspension surgery.

Treatment of urinary incontinence:

Type of urinary Incontinence

Stress urinary Incontinence

Urgency urinary Incontinence

Overflow Incontinence

Step 1
  • Lifestyle
  • Weight loss in obese individuals
  • Reduce fluid and caffeine intake
  • Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks)
  • Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day

If non-obstructive pathology

  • Continuous catheter drainage
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Step 2
  • Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises)
  • Biofeedback therapy
  • Scheduled Voiding
  • Bladder retraining
  • Scheduled voiding

If obstructive pathology

  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Urethroplasty for urethral strictures

Step 3

Medical Treatment

  • Estrogen
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (α-adrenergic) Imipramine

Medical Treatment

  • Anticholinergics:
  1. Oxybutynin
  2. Tolterodine
  3. Fesoterodine fumarate
  4. Darifenacin
  • Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* )
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine)
  

Step 4

Devices

  • Pessary
  • Urethral Inserts

Neuromodulation

  • Sacral nerve stimulation
  • Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection

 

  

Step 5

Surgical Treatment

  • Colposuspension
  • Midurethral tape

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT)

Transobturator tape (TOT)

  • Microslings
  • Bladder neck suspension
  • Bulking agents injection
  • Others

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK)

Paravaginal repair

Surgical Treatment

  • Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity)
  • Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit)
  
  • Note: Mirabegron contraindicated in severe uncontrolled hypertension systolic blood pressure ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≤ 110 mm Hg, or both
  • Mirabegron is better tolerated than antimuscarinics in older patients and can be considered as an alternative to antimuscarinics for elderly patients.

questions.text: A stillborn fetus is discovered during a routine prenatal checkup. The fetus shows skin slippage on the face and back, soft and flaccid tissues, and a sweetish disagreeable smell, but no gas formation. The skull shows mild cranial compression but no overlapping of cranial sutures. Based on these findings, approximately how long ago did fetal death likely occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Between 36-48 hours ago

 

Explanation:

  • The baby shows signs of maceration such as skin slippage (occurs as early as 12 hours) & cranial compression (occurs after 36 hours) but no overlapping of cranial sutures (occurs >96 hours), which indicates fetal demise occurred after 36 hours but before 96 hours.

 

Maceration:

  • It is a process of aseptic autolysis of dead fetus inside the womb.
  • This occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii and with exclusion of air.

 

Maceration changes in intrauterine death

Time Since Death

Maceration changes observed

12 hours

Earliest sign: Skin slippage of face, back, or abdomen

24 hours

Skin becomes brown or purplish in color

> 36 hours

Cranial compression becomes visible

72 hours (3 days)

Desquamation over 75% of body surface

> 96 hours (4 days)

Overlapping of cranial sutures

> 1 week

Mouth is widely open

Throughout process
  • Fetus is soft and flaccid
  • Sweetish disagreeable smell
  • No gas formation
  • Internal organs show autolytic decomposition (except lungs and uterus)

Less than 12 hours ago (Option A) is incorrect because skin slippage is already present, which doesn't occur until at least 12 hours after death.

Between 12-24 hours ago (Option B) is incorrect because while skin slippage is present, the cranial compression indicates more time has passed.

More than 96 hours ago (Option D) is incorrect because while cranial compression is present, overlapping cranial sutures are absent, which would be expected after 96 hours.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of asthma is undergoing elective surgery. He is induced with isoflurane and given succinylcholine for muscle relaxation. Within minutes, the surgical team observes that he has developed severe muscle rigidity, a rapid heart rate, and a notable increase in body temperature. Which drug/s is/are most likely responsible for the onset of these symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both isoflurane and succinylcholine

 

Explanation:

  • In this case, the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia is typically made based on the presence of characteristic clinical signs—such as muscle rigidity, tachycardia, and hyperthermia—following exposure to certain anaesthetic agents.
  • Both isoflurane (an inhaled anaesthetic) and succinylcholine (a depolarizing muscle relaxant) are well-known triggers for malignant hyperthermia.
  • The combination of these agents heightens the risk of developing this serious condition, which is indicated by the rapid onset of symptoms in the patient after their administration.

 

Triggers of Malignant Hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled general anesthetics
    • Ether
    • Halothane
    • Enflurane
    • Isoflurane
    • Desflurane
    • Sevoflurane
  • Depolarizing muscle relaxant
    • Succinylcholine
  • Prior exercise, even just an hour before anaesthesia induction, intensifies the severity and accelerates the onset of rigidity.

 

Initial Indicators of Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) During Anesthesia:

  • Muscle rigidity
  • Masseter spasm
  • Tachycardia
  • Unexplained hypercarbia
  • Increased temperature

 

Other Features:

  • Cyanosis, metabolic acidosis, hypertension, fever, sweating,
  • Hyperkalemia, Hyperphosphatemia, Myoglobinemia, Myoglobinuria, Cardiac Arrest, DIC, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of Type IV RTA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Either A or B

 

Explanation:

Type IV RTA is due to impaired aldosterone production (hypoaldosteronism) or impaired renal responsiveness to aldosterone (pseudohypoaldosteronism)

 

Hyperkalemic Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) = Type IV RTA

 

Etiology

Impaired aldosterone production (hypoaldosteronism) or impaired renal responsiveness to aldosterone (pseudohypoaldosteronism) (Option C)

Pathogenesis

Lack of aldosterone→Hyperkalemia

↓

H+/ATPase function affected

↓

Impaired hydrogen secretion

↓

Acidosis

Clinical Manifestations
  • Growth failure within the first few years of life
  • Polyuria
  • Dehydration (due to salt wasting)
  • Severe Cases: Life-threatening hyperkalemia
  • Obstructive Uropathies

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy exhibits extreme jealousy toward his mother’s close relationship with her new partner, showing signs of distress when she pays attention to anyone else. What psychological complex might this behaviour suggest?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Oedipus Complex

 

Explanation:

  • The boy's jealousy towards his mother's attention to others indicates an unconscious desire for exclusivity with her, characteristic of the Oedipus complex.

 

Oedipus Complex

Electra Complex

Pharaoh Complex

Refers to a son’s sexual desire for his mother.

Refers to a daughter’s sexual desire for her father. (Option B ruled out)

Refers to a brother’s sexual desire for his sister. (Option A ruled out)

 

  • These complexes are associated with psychological issues and may be rooted in early-life trauma or unresolved conflicts.
  • Individuals exhibiting these complexes may have psychopathic tendencies.

 

Narcissistic Complex (Option D):

  • While narcissism involves self-centeredness, it does not specifically relate to the jealousy exhibited in the context of family dynamics and maternal attachment.
  • It is usually characterized by self-love which may or may not be associated with genital excitation.

questions.text:
A 55 year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, tachypnea, and altered mental status. BP is 100/60 mm Hg 

Laboratory results show:


	WBC: 14,000/μL
	Serum lactate: 1.8 mmol/L
	Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL)


Chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. The patient requires 6 L/min of oxygen to maintain  pO2 of 90 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Sepsis 

According to the Sepsis-3 criteria , sepsis is defined as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. The clinical criteria for sepsis include:

  1. Suspected infection
  2. An acute increase of ≥2  point in SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment)  

In this case:

  • The patient has a suspected lung infection (fever and chest X-ray infiltrate).
  • There is evidence of organ dysfunction:
    • Respiratory: PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 200 . PaO₂ = 90 mm Hg

    • Oxygen flow rate = 6 L/min via nasal cannula

    • Estimated FiO₂ at 6 L/min ≈ 45% = 0.45

    • so PaO2/FiO2= 90/0.45 = 200 

    • Renal: Creatinine increase > 0.3 mg/dL from baseline

This meets the Sepsis-3 criteria for sepsis.

 

SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) Score:

The SOFA score is a more comprehensive tool used to assess organ dysfunction in potentially septic patients. It evaluates six organ systems:

  1. Respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 ratio)
  2. Cardiovascular (Mean arterial pressure and vasopressor requirements)
  3. Hepatic (Bilirubin level)
  4. Coagulation (Platelet count)
  5. Renal (Creatinine level or urine output)
  6. Neurological (Glasgow Coma Scale)

Each system is scored from 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating more severe dysfunction. A total SOFA score ranges from 0 to 24.

questions.text:
Which of the following steps in the Citric acid cycle involves oxidative phosphorylation and decarboxylation?


	Isocitrate → α-Ketoglutarate
	Succinate → Fumarate
	Malate → Oxaloacetate
	α-Ketoglutarate → Succinyl-CoA
questions.solution:
• The enzymes involved in both reactions are Isocitrate Dehydrogenase (Step 1) and α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase (Step 4).
  • Both involve oxidation and removal of CO₂ and produce NADH, which is later used in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Steps 3 and 4 are catalysed by Succinate dehydrogenase, and Malate Dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidation of malate to oxaloacetate, producing NADH, which enters oxidative phosphorylation.

Krebs cycle:

 

Reactions in Krebs cycle:

Reaction Type Enzyme Reaction Product Formed
Oxidative Decarboxylation Isocitrate Dehydrogenase Isocitrate → α-Ketoglutarate CO₂ + NADH
α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase α-Ketoglutarate → Succinyl-CoA CO₂ + NADH
Oxidation (Production of NADH/FADH₂) Isocitrate Dehydrogenase Isocitrate → α-Ketoglutarate NADH
α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase α-Ketoglutarate → Succinyl-CoA NADH
Succinate Dehydrogenase Succinate → Fumarate FADH₂
Malate Dehydrogenase Malate → Oxaloacetate NADH
Substrate-Level Phosphorylation Succinyl-CoA Synthetase Succinyl-CoA → Succinate GTP (or ATP)
Hydration Fumarase Fumarate → Malate H₂O Addition
  • Oxidative Decarboxylation removes CO₂ and generates NADH.
  • Oxidation reactions contribute to the Electron Transport Chain by generating NADH/FADH₂.
  • Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs at the Succinyl-CoA to Succinate step.
  • Hydration reaction occurs when Fumarase converts Fumarate to Malate.

questions.text:
Match the following research trials/programs with their respective objectives:


	
		
			
			i) MRFIT
			
			
			a. Surveillance and assessment of trends in cardiovascular events
			
		
		
			
			ii) Jai vigyan mission
			
			
			b. Decreasing serum cholesterol, diastolic BP, smoking cessation in lowering coronary heart disease mortality
			
		
		
			
			iii) MONICA
			
			
			c. Dietary approaches to stop HTN
			
		
		
			
			iv) MPOWER
			
			
			d. To control rheumatic heart disease
			
		
		
			
			v) DASH
			
			
			e. To control consumption of Tobacco
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) i-b, ii-d, iii-a, iv-e, v-c


Explanation:

Multiple risk factor intervention Trial (MRFIT)
  • It is a randomised, primary prevention trial
  • Its objective is to check whether decreasing high levels of serum cholesterol, DBP and smoking cessation would help in reducing coronary heart disease mortality.

MPOWER
  • Monitor tobacco use and prevention policies
  • Protect people from use of tobacco
  • Offer help for quitting tobacco use
  • Warn about the dangers with tobacco use
  • Enforce bans on tobacco advertising, promotion and sponsorship
  • Raise taxes on tobacco

MONICA
  • Monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease
  • Surveillance and assessment in trends of cardiovascular disease

Dietary approaches to stop hypertension

(DASH)
  • Consume a diet rich in vegetables, fruits and low fat dairy products with low content of saturated and total fats
  • Helps in decreasing around 8-14 mm hg of SBP

Jai Vigyan mission
  • Surveillance for finding out epidemiological determinants for Group A strep and sore throat.
  • Establishment of registry of RHD/RF all over the country
  • To promote vaccine development
  • To promote research and studies for investigations of RHD/RF

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty urinating and a history of profuse, creamy urethral discharge. He reports a prior untreated sexually transmitted infection. The urethrogram of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of difficulty urinating and a history of profuse, creamy urethral discharge strongly suggest a gonococcal infection, which can lead to inflammation and scarring in the bulbar urethra, resulting in a stricture. The urethrogram findings of narrowing specifically in the bulbar urethra support this diagnosis.

 

Parts of urethra

 

Bulbar urethral stricture

• Stricture seen in the bulbar urethra.

• Common in gonorrhoea.

• Presents with profuse, purulent or mucopurulent urethral discharge.

Stricture of distal penile urethra

• Urethrogram showing narrowing in the distal urethra.

 

Urethral carcinoma (Option A): Less likely due to the absence of risk factors and the typical presentation of malignancy, which would not match the history of an untreated STI.

 

Penile urethral stricture (Option C): Unlikely, as the urethrogram shows narrowing in the bulbar urethra, and penile strictures are less common in this context.

 

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) (Option D): Unlikely due to the patient's younger age and specific symptoms that align more with a urethral stricture rather than bladder outlet obstruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy for the treatment of Graves' disease. Two days postoperatively, she presents with numbness and tingling around her mouth and in her fingers. She also complains of muscle cramps and mild weakness. Laboratory tests reveal decreased serum calcium levels. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms following the surgery?

choices.text: Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of numbness, tingling, muscle cramps, and decreased serum calcium levels indicate hypocalcemia.
  • The most common cause of hypocalcemia following thyroid surgery is damage to the parathyroid glands or their blood supply.

 

HYPOPARATHYROIDISM

Common Causes:

Thyroid Surgery

Most frequent cause is damage to the parathyroid glands or their blood supply. (Option B)

Risk Factors:

  • Bilateral neck exploration,
  • Extensive central neck dissection,
  • Revision surgery,
  • Thyroidectomy for Graves' disease,
  • Pediatric patients.

Autoimmune Disorders

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

Genetic Conditions

DiGeorge syndrome, autosomal dominant hypocalcemia.

Radiation Therapy

Radiation to the neck area can damage parathyroid glands.

Medications

Lithium, and some chemotherapeutic agents (Pembrolizumab).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after a severe anaphylactic reaction to a bee sting. The patient is in obvious distress, with signs of airway swelling, difficulty breathing, and low blood pressure. The emergency team prepares to administer adrenaline to stabilise the patient. What is the correct dilution and route of administration for adrenaline in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1:1,000 dilution, intramuscular injection

 

Exolanation:

  • In this scenario, the correct dilution of adrenaline for administration is 1:1,000.
  • In severe cases, the preferred route is an intramuscular injection (on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh); it ensures rapid absorption and onset of action, crucial in managing anaphylaxis.

 

Uses of epinephrine:

Condition

Use

Dilution/Concentration

Route of Administration

Anaphylaxis

First-line treatment for severe allergic reactions

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Intramuscular (IM)

Cardiac arrest

To restore cardiac rhythm and blood pressure

1:10,000 (0.1 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV)
  • Intraosseous (IO)

Asthma

Treatment of acute severe asthma attacks

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Inhalation via nebulizer
  • Intramuscular (IM)
  • subcutaneous (SC)

Hypotension

To increase blood pressure

1:100,000 (0.01 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV) infusion

Local anesthesia

Enhance duration and intensity of local anesthetic effect

1:200,000 to 1:100,000 (0.005 to 0.01 mg/mL)
  • Local injection

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent bacterial infections, delayed wound healing, and poor pus formation. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SLC35C1 gene, leading to the deficient synthesis of Sialyl Lewis X (SLex). Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this deficiency?

choices.text: Impaired leukocyte rolling and weak adhesion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Impaired leukocyte adhesion

Explanation:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Defective leukocyte rolling and weak adhesion because of mutations in fucosyl transferase required for the synthesis of sialylated oligosaccharide (receptor for selectins)

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 3

LAD-III is caused by mutations in the FERMT3 gene, which encodes kindlin-3, a cytoskeletal protein. These mutations disrupt the signalling of integrins on platelets and leukocytes, which impairs cellular adhesion
  • The deficiency of Sialyl Lewis X (SLex), caused by mutations in the SLC35C1 gene in Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency Type 2 (LAD-2), leads to impaired leukocyte adhesion.
  • SLex is a crucial glycoconjugate involved in the adhesion of leukocytes to endothelial cells, facilitating their migration from the bloodstream into tissues during inflammation or infection.

Defective opsonisation (Option B):

  • Opsonisation is the process by which immune cells, particularly phagocytes like neutrophils and macrophages, mark pathogens or foreign particles for phagocytosis.
  • This marking is often facilitated by opsonins such as antibodies or complement proteins.
  • A defect in opsonisation would lead to impaired recognition and clearance of pathogens by phagocytes, potentially increasing susceptibility to infections.

Reduced chemokine production (Option C):

  • Chemokines are signalling molecules that play a key role in immune cell migration, including leukocyte recruitment to sites of infection or inflammation.
  • Reduced production of chemokines could result in inadequate recruitment of leukocytes to sites of infection, potentially leading to compromised immune responses.

Increased neutrophil apoptosis (Option D):

  • Apoptosis, or programmed cell death, is a regulated process in various cell types, including neutrophils.
  • Increased neutrophil apoptosis could affect the lifespan and function of these immune cells, potentially impacting immune responses and pathogen clearance.

questions.text: A forensic investigator is analyzing a crime scene for potential blood stains. They decide to use a presumptive test that can detect trace amounts of blood but may also give false positives with other substances like bleach or rust. Which of the following is the most appropriate test for this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Luminol

 

Explanation:

  • Luminol is widely used for detecting trace amounts of blood.
  • It reacts with hemoglobin and produces a chemiluminescent glow in the dark.
  • However, it can yield false positives with substances like bleach or metals.

 

Blood Stain Screening Tests in Forensic Medicine

Presumptive Tests

  • Luminol:
    • Detects trace blood stains by reacting with hemoglobin.
    • Produces a chemiluminescent glow in the dark.
    • Prone to false positives (e.g., with metals or bleach).

  • Forensic Bluestar: (Option D ruled out)
    • Offers rapid results and can be used for DNA analysis afterward.
    • Similar to Luminol but also has a risk of false positives.
  • Kastle Meyer Test: (Option A ruled out)
    • High specificity but lower sensitivity.
    • Detects blood at 1:16,384 dilution.
  • Hemastix: (Option B ruled out)
    • More sensitive than Kastle Meyer (detects blood at 1:64 dilution).
    • Less specific, with false positives from substances like tomatoes or rust.

Principles of Blood Detection Tests:

Test

Working Principle

Kastle-Meyer

Hemoglobin catalyzes the oxidation of phenolphthalein, resulting in a pink color.

Hemastix

Reagent reacts with hemoglobin, causing a color change based on the concentration of hemoglobin.

Luminol

Chemiluminescent reaction occurs when luminol reacts with hemoglobin under alkaline conditions, producing a blue glow.

Forensic Bluestar

Similar to luminol, but with enhanced sensitivity; it reacts with hemoglobin to produce a bright blue luminescence.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, fixed, non-tender, lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 cm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage III

 

Explanation:

 

The patient in this scenario has a T2 tumor (>2 cm in size) with the involvement of two inguinal lymph nodes (N2a). According to the FIGO staging for invasive vulvar cancer, this clinical presentation corresponds to Stage IIIA.

 

Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer

Stage 1

Limited to vulva.

1a

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis 

1b

Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes 

Stage II

Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes

Stage III

Tumor of any size with extension to upper ⅔ vagina, upper ⅔ urethra, bladder, or rectum.

IIIa

Regional LN ≤ 5 mm 

IIIb

Regional LN > 5 mm

IIIc

Regional LN with extracapsular spread.

Stage IV

  

IVa

Tumor invades any of the following:

  1. upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  2. Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. 

IVb

Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes

Regional LN refers to inguinal and femoral lymph nodes.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presented with behavioral changes and involuntary movements over the past several weeks. Neurological examination revealed ataxia and myoclonus. He passed away after 4 months, and biopsy findings of the brain tissue are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?




	Proteinaceous particles with single-stranded RNA cause it.
	It results from the misfolding of PrPsc to PrPc.
	Spongiform transformation is a characteristic histopathological feature
	It is associated with a good prognosis if diagnosed early.
	Familial forms are associated with specific genetic mutations.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this clinical presentation is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a prion disease.

 

Prion Disease or Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE):

  • Prions are proteinaceous infectious particles with no RNA/DNA.
  • Pathogenesis: Misfolding of normal prion protein (PrPc) to form beta-pleated configuration (PrPSc).
  • Histopathology: Spongiform vacuolisation inside the cell.
  • Associated diseases:

Types of prion disease
1. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M/C)

  • Genetic: Familial form caused by PRNP mutation.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic
  • Symptoms:
    • Dementia.
    • Associated pronounced involuntary jerking muscle contractions on sudden stimulation (startle myoclonus) and cerebellar dysfunction (ataxia).
  • Histopathogenesis:
    • Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex.
  • Prognosis: Uniformly fatal with average survival < 7 months after the onset of symptoms.

2. Kuru disease

  • PAS & Congo: red positive.
  • Kuru plaques: Extracellular aggregated abnormal PrP.

3. Fatal familial insomnia

4. Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a history of involuntary bedwetting during sleep at least twice a week for the past 6 months. Physical examination and laboratory investigations reveal no abnormalities. The child has no daytime urinary symptoms or signs of urinary tract infection. After ruling out organic causes, what is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Imipramine

 

Explanation:

  • Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant with anticholinergic properties, is effective in treating childhood nocturnal enuresis by reducing bedwetting episodes.
  • However, desmopressin remains the preferred drug of choice for this condition.

Amitriptyline (Option A) is a TCA commonly used to treat depression and neuropathic pain.

  • While it shares similarities with imipramine in terms of pharmacological class, it is not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis. 
  • It can also be used for migraine prophylaxis.

Amoxapine (Option B) is a TCA that inhibits norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake and acts as a dopamine receptor antagonist.

  • It is used primarily for major depressive disorder and psychotic depression.
  • It is not commonly used for nocturnal enuresis. 
  • Side effect of amoxapine - EPS

Clomipramine (Option C) is another TCA, mainly used to treat obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and depression.

  • It is not typically used for bedwetting and can have several side effects, including sedation and anticholinergic effects.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with swelling and pain in the region of the parotid gland, accompanied by ear discharge. Examination of the external auditory canal (EAC) reveals signs of infection. Which bony anatomical structure is responsible for the spread of infection between the EAC and the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foramen of Huschke

 

Explanation:

  • Foramen of Huschke: A deficiency in the anteroinferior bony EAC, present in some children under four and occasionally into adulthood.
  • It allows infection to spread between the parotid gland and the EAC. (Option B)
  • Fissures of Santorini: Two gaps in the cartilage of the outer EAC that allow infection to pass between the parotid glands and the EAC.
  • Isthmus: A narrowing in the bony EAC, about 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane. It is not an opening but a constriction in the canal. (Option C)

Tympanic membrane (Option D):

  • The tympanic membrane separates the external ear from the middle ear and is not involved in spreading infections to the parotid gland.

Mastoid Air Cells (Option A):

  • Mastoid air cells are a series of air-filled spaces located within the mastoid process of the temporal bone, adjacent to the middle ear.
  • While infections in the middle ear (otitis media) can spread to the mastoid air cells (causing mastoiditis), they do not directly connect the EAC to the parotid gland.
  • Thus, they are not responsible for the spread of infection between these two areas.

questions.text: Gram stain of a painful genital ulcer exudate shows gram-negative coccobacilli in a "school of fish" arrangement. Which statement about the suspected pathogen is correct?

choices.text: Requires X factor but not V factor; grows on vancomycin-supplemented chocolate agar
"Pushing test" is diagnostic; further laboratory confirmation unnecessary
Multiplex PCR is less sensitive than culture for diagnosis
Single-dose azithromycin; partner treatment optional if asymptomatic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Requires X factor but not V factor; grows on vancomycin-supplemented chocolate agar

 

Explanation:

H. ducreyi requires X factor (hemin) but not V factor. Chocolate agar supplemented with vancomycin is the optimal culture medium, providing necessary nutrients and inhibiting normal flora.

Features of H. ducreyi:

  • Gram-negative coccobacillus
  • Fastidious, requiring X factor but not V factor
  • Forms characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" arrangements in Gram stains
  • Safety pin appearance of bipolar staining.

Clinical features of chancroid:

  • Painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and a purulent base
  • Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)
  • Incubation period of 3-10 days

Diagnosis:

  1. Clinical presentation
  2. Gram stain of ulcer exudate
  3. Culture on selective media (challenging and low sensitivity)
  4. PCR (most sensitive method)
  5. Differential diagnosis includes syphilis, herpes simplex, and lymphogranuloma venereum

Treatment:

  • Azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR
  • Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose, OR
  • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days, OR
  • Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days
  • Treatment of sexual partners is crucial

 

"Pushing test" is diagnostic; further laboratory confirmation unnecessary (Option B):

  • The "pushing test" is suggestive but not diagnostic for chancroid. Laboratory confirmation is still necessary.
  • The push test is a method used to identify Haemophilus ducreyi colonies on an agar surface by gently pushing them with a toothpick:
  • H. ducreyi colonies are cohesive and remain intact when pushed across the agar surface.
  • The colonies are typically translucent to semi-opaque, yellow-gray in color, and pinpoint in size.

 

Multiplex PCR is less sensitive than culture for diagnosis (Option C): Multiplex PCR is more sensitive than culture for H. ducreyi diagnosis, not less.

 

Single-dose azithromycin; partner treatment optional if asymptomatic (Option D): While single-dose azithromycin is a recommended treatment, partner treatment is necessary regardless of symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following breast lesions are correctly paired with their histopathological characteristics?

 


	
		
			
			1.  Fibrocystic changes
			
			
		
		
			
			2.  Duct ectasia
			
			
		
		
			
			3.  Phyllodes tumor
			
			
		
		
			
			4.  Invasive Ductal Carcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4

Explanation

Breast tumors with their histopathological findings:

Fibrocystic changes

Cysts: Fluid-filled sacs within the breast tissue, often surrounded by fibrous tissue.

Fibrosis: Thickening and scarring of breast tissue, which may result in palpable lumps or areas of increased density on imaging studies.

Apocrine Metaplasia: Transformation of ductal epithelial cells into apocrine-like cells, characterized by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and apical snouts.

Duct ectasia

A lot of foamy macrophages, periductal lymphocytic infiltrates can be observed.

Phyllodes tumor

Increased stromal cellularity and overgrowth, giving rise to the typical leaf-like architecture.

Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS)

Types of DCIS:

  • Micropapillary tumors: Additional epithelial cells within the lumen.
  • Cribriform tumors: Ducts filled with cells that form multiple lumena.
  • Solid tumors: Completely filled ducts.
  • Comedo tumors: Solid with a necrotic core

Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC)

Shows more mucin both extracellular and intracellular with signet ring cells.

Fibroadenoma

Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule, with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components.

  • Intracanalicular fibroadenoma - Ducts are compressed.

  • Pericanalicular fibroadenoma - Ducts are open.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with worsening ascites, oliguria, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals tense ascites, mild jaundice, and peripheral edema. Laboratory investigations show:

Serum creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL (baseline: 0.9 mg/dL)

Serum sodium: 126 mEq/L

Urine sodium: <10 mEq/L

Albumin infusion is planned as part of his management. What is the recommended dosage of albumin infusion for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1g/kg per day

 

Explanation:

  • The patient likely has Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS), a complication of advanced liver disease characterized by renal dysfunction due to splanchnic vasodilation and reduced renal perfusion.
  • HRS is diagnosed based on clinical features, including worsening renal function, low urine sodium (<10 mEq/L), and exclusion of other causes of acute kidney injury (e.g., hypovolemia, nephrotoxicity).
  • The recommended dosage of albumin infusion in HRS is 1 g/kg per day, up to a maximum of 100 g/day, to expand intravascular volume and improve renal perfusion.
  • This is used in combination with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin or norepinephrine to reverse the underlying renal vasoconstriction.
  • Higher doses (e.g., 2-5 g/kg/day) are avoided due to risks such as pulmonary edema.

 

Treatment of Hepatorenal syndrome:

  • Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with right-sided visual field loss in both eyes, resulting in a homonymous hemianopic defect. Neuroimaging and clinical examination suggest a lesion affecting the visual pathway. Based on the above findings, which anatomical location is most likely implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left optic tract

 

Explanation:

  • A lesion in the left optic tract would cause right (contralateral) homonymous hemianopia, where the right visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Location of the lesion

Characteristic features

Optic nerve
  • Marked loss of vision or complete blindness on the affected side associated.
  • Near (accommodation) reflex is present.

Optic chiasma
  • Bitemporal hemianopia

Optic tract
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
  • Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction.

Optic radiations
  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky)
    • Produced when the inferior fibres (Meyer’s loop) are involved in temporal lobe lesions)
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor)
    • Produced when superior fibres (Baum’s loop) are involved in parietal lobe lesions.

Visual cortex
  • Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents for a routine eye examination. His intraocular pressure (IOP) is consistently measured at 23 mm Hg on multiple occasions. He reports no visual symptoms, and his fundus examination shows no abnormalities. Visual field testing reveals no defects. Based on these findings, which of the following diagnoses is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ocular Hypertension

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has elevated IOP consistently above 21 mm Hg without any visual field defects or fundus changes.
  • These characteristics are consistent with ocular hypertension.

 

ASPECT

Ocular Hypertension

 

Characteristic Features
  • IOP consistently above 21 mm Hg (No Damage)
  • No Fundus findings
  • No visual field defects

Risk Factors
  • Consistent IOP >30 mm Hg.
  • Central corneal thickness <550 µm.
  • Vertical cup-to-disc ratio >0.7.
  • Increased age.
  • Increased pattern standard deviation (PSD) on Humphrey visual field test.
  • Disc hemorrhages (splinter hemorrhages near or over the disc).

Management
  • When these risk factors are present, treatment may be initiated similarly to open-angle glaucoma, but with a less aggressive approach.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct match of brainstem components with the respective cranial nerve nuclei that originate from them?

 


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			a. Midbrain
			
			
			1. Trigeminal nerve
			
		
		
			
			b. Pons
			
			
			2. Oculomotor nerve
			
		
		
			
			c. Medulla oblongata
			
			
			3. Glossopharyngeal nerve
			
		
		
			
			d. Pontomedullary junction
			
			
			4. Facial nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-1, c-3, d-4

Explanation:

Components of brainstem

Cranial nerves nuclei

Midbrain

Oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV)

Pons

Trigeminal (V)

Medulla oblongata

Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), cranial accessory (XIcr) and hypoglossal (XII)

Pontomedullary junction

Abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent headaches. She describes a severe throbbing headache on the right side of her head associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. Triptans are being considered. Which of the following is the fastest-acting oral triptan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rizatriptan

Explanation:

  • Rizatriptan has the fastest onset of action among oral triptans and it is useful for acute migraine attacks requiring rapid relief.
  • The onset of relief begins within 30 minutes, which is quicker than other oral triptans.
  • It is highly lipophilic, allowing faster blood-brain barrier penetration.
